author: ClaudiaAssis
content:
ITT Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    ITT, -0.46%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         said late Thursday Chief Executive and President Denise Ramos has decided to retire. Ramos will serve as CEO until Jan. 1, and will fill an advisory role until retirement on March 1, 2019. Luca Savi was promoted to the newly created role of president and chief operating officer, and Savi will become CEO and president on Jan. 1. Shares of ITT were flat in late trading, after ending the regular trading session up 1%.
title: ITT's CEO Denise Ramos to retire in January

author: ClaudiaAssis
content:
Callaway Golf Co. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    ELY, +0.45%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares rose more than 7% late Thursday after the maker of golf clubs and other equipment topped second-quarter views and raised its 2018 revenue and profit outlooks. Callaway said it earned $61 million, or 63 cents a share, in the quarter, compared with $31 million, or 33 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales rose 30% to $396 million, compared with $305 million a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected earnings of 47 cents a share on sales of $371 million. Callaway raised its 2018 sales outlook to between $1.210 billion and $1.225 billion, compared with a prior range between $1.170 billion and $1.185 billion. Full-year 2018 EPS guidance moved up to between 95 cents and $1, compared with an earlier guidance between 77 cents and 82 cents. The analysts surveyed by FactSet expect full-year EPS of 82 cents on sales of $1.19 billion. Shares ended the regular trading day up 2.1%.
title: Callaway Golf shares rally 7% after company tops views, raises guidance

content: A previous version incorrectly stated adjusted earnings per share for the fiscal first quarter.

author: SueChang
content:
Acacia Communications Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    ACIA, +0.70%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares rallied in Thursday's extended session after the optical networking technology company issued a strong third-quarter outlook. Acacia reported it swung to a second-quarter net loss of $3.2 million, or 8 cents a share, from a net income of $4.7 million, or 11 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue slid to $65 millon from $78.9 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast a loss of 8 cents a share on revenue of $63.3 million. The company projected third-quarter adjusted revenue of $86 million to $94 million and earnings per share of 10 cents to 22 cents. Wall Street is predicting revenue of $73.7 million and EPS of 8 cents. Acacia shares jumped 5.5%.
title: Acacia stock surges on strong third-quarter outlook

author: MaxA.Cherney
content:
Activision Blizzard Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    ATVI, +0.16%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares fell 2.2% in the extended session Thursday after the company beat earnings expectations but issued weaker-than-expected third-quarter outlook. The videogame company reported second-quarter net income of $402 million, or 52 cents a share, compared with $243 million, or 32 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted for items such as share-based compensation, earnings were 62 cents a share. Revenue rose to $1.64 billion from $1.63 billion in the year-ago period but analysts use net bookings, which takes into account physical and digital sales among other things, to determine estimates. Activision reported net bookings fell to $1.38 billion from $1.42 billion in the year-earlier quarter. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated adjusted earnings of 35 cents a share on net bookings of $1.38 billion. For the third quarter, analysts model adjusted earnings of 66 cents a share on net bookings of $1.88 billion. The company said it expects third-quarter adjusted earnings of 37 cents a share on net bookings of $1.61 billion. Activision stock gained 1.3% during regular trading and is up 17% this year. The S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         rose 5.8% in the same period.
title: Activision stock jittery after earnings beat, weak outlook

author: MaxA.Cherney
content:
Take-Two Interactive Software Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    TTWO, +2.88%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares shot up more than 8% in after hours trading Thursday after the company reported fiscal first-quarter earnings. The company reported first-quarter net income of $71.7 million, or 62 cents a share, compared with $60.3 million, or 56 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $388 million from $418.2 million in the year-ago period but analysts use the net bookings figure for estimates. Take-Two reported net bookings of $288.3 million, up from $348 million in the year-ago quarter. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated net bookings of $260 million and for the second fiscal quarter analysts model net bookings of $586 million. The company said it expects fiscal second-quarter earnings of 43 cents to 53 cents a share on net bookings of $500 million to $550 million. Take-Two shares closed up 0.8% to $113.16 during regular trading and Take-Two stock has gained 3.1% this year. The S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         rose 5.8% during the same period.
title: Take-Two stock rises 8% after earnings

author: SueChang
content:
Shares of Shake Shack Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SHAK, +0.19%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         fell in Thursday's extended session after the casual restaurant chain issued a weak same-stores sales guidance for 2018. Shake Shack reported its second-quarter earnings rose to $7.6 million, or 26 cents per Class A share, from $4.9 million, or 19 cents per Class A share, a year ago. On an adjusted basis, it would have earned 29 cents a share. Revenue grew 27% to $116.3 million while same-store sales rose 1.1%. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast earnings of 18 cents a share on revenue of $111 million. The company now expects 2018 revenue in a range of $446 million to $450 million. However, same-store sales are projected to be either flat or grow 1%, slower than the average 1.2% forecast by analysts. Shake Shack shares declined 5.8% after hours.
title: Shake Shack shares drop nearly 6% on weak same-store sales outlook

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
GoPro Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    GPRO, -3.40%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares jumped in after-hours trading Thursday after the action-camera company lost less money and produced higher revenues than expected. GoPro reported a second-quarter net loss of $37.3 million, or 27 cents a share, on sales of $282.7 million. After adjustments for stock-based compensation and other effects, GoPro claimed a loss of 15 cents a share. Analysts on average expected an adjusted loss of 22 cents a share on sales of $270 million. "We believe GoPro will be profitable in the second half of 2018," GoPro Chief Executive Nick Woodman said in Thursday's release. GoPro's stock moved about 8% higher in late trading immediately following the release of the report, continuing a recent surge. GoPro shares have increased 20.5% in the last three months, while the S&P 500 index

                                         has gained 6.7% in that time.
title: GoPro stock shoots higher after earnings

author: TomiKilgore
content:
Tesla Inc. shares 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    TSLA, +0.86%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         ran up 14.6% in afternoon trade, in the wake of second-quarter results, putting them on track for the biggest one-day post-earnings rally in over five years. The last time the stock rose at least this much the day after earnings was May 9, 2013, when it soared 24.4% after the electric car maker reported first-quarter 2013 results. Over the 21 quarters since then, the average gain on post-earnings up days has been 6.8%, while the average decline on post-earnings down days has been 7.5%. Overall, the average one-day post-earnings move in either direction is 7.1%, while the median move is 6.4%. There are a lot of investors who aren't happy with Thursday's stock price surge, as Tesla shares are the most heavily shorted in the U.S. market, according to S3 Partners LLC, a financial analytics firm. The stock has now gained 11% year to date, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has advanced 5.8%.
title: Tesla's stock heads toward best 1-day post-earnings rally in over 5 years

author: EmmaCourt
content:
DexCom Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DXCM, +0.13%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares surged nearly 30% in extremely heavy Thursday trade after the company reported a second-quarter revenue beat and narrower-than-expected loss. Earnings for the latest quarter rose to $30.2 million, or 34 cents per share, after $2.9 million, or 3 cents per share in the year-earlier period. The company said it had an adjusted loss per share of 10 cents, excluding 48 cents per share in income from an investment in Tandem Diabetes Care as well as interest expense on senior convertible notes. The FactSet consensus was a loss of 18 cents per share. Revenue rose to $242.5 million from $170.6 million, above the FactSet consensus of $205.8 million. The company attributed its latest earnings to significant adoption of continuous glucose monitors, which patients use to manage their diabetes more easily. The performance was "particularly notable" because the company's G6 platform -- a new iteration of the device that integrates with a smartphone, has a sensor that lasts 10 days and doesn't require a fingerstick test to measure blood sugar levels -- was only launched late in the quarter, Chief Executive Kevin Sayer noted. DexCom also raised its 2018 revenue guidance from a range of $850 million to $860 million to about $925 million. Company shares have lifted 66% over the last three months, compared with a 7.2% rise in the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         and a 5.8% rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%
title: Dexcom stock surges 30% on better-than-expected revenue results

author: SteveGoldstein
content: There's a record high number of unfilled job openings at small business, the National Federation of Independent Business reported, citing its survey of small-business owners. The NFIB said a net 37% of owners have job openings they haven't filled. Job openings are most frequent in construction (57%), manufacturing (46%), and wholesale trades (45%). The percent that used temporary workers rose a point to 13%, the NFIB added. A seasonally-adjusted net 23% are planning to create new jobs, up two points from June's 21 percent. The Labor Department will report July jobs numbers on Friday.
title: Record number of job openings for small business, NFIB says

author: MarkDeCambre
content:
The Dow Jones Industrial Average was slumping in midday trade, even as one of its key components, Apple, was flirting with a close at a major psychological benchmark. The Dow 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         was most recently off 23 points, or 0.1%, at 25,305, with worries about a fresh clash between the U.S. and China overshadowing Apple Inc.'s 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AAPL, -0.30%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         attempt to finish Thursday's trade as the first U.S. company to boast a $1 trillion market value in history (not adjusted for inflation). Apple hit a share peak at $207.05 in intraday trade, enough of a climb to drive it to that closely watched level, briefly. However, declines in industrial giants Boeing Co. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    BA, -1.25%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         as well as DowDuPont Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DWDP, -1.85%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         and fast-food franchise McDonald's Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    MCD, -0.39%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         were combining to exact a hefty toll on the price-weighted Dow. Apple's share gain, meanwhile, was contributing about 32 points to the gauge. A $1 move in any one of the Dow's 30 components equates to a 6.8-point swing in the blue-chip benchmark. Other indexes, notably the Nasdaq Composite 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    COMP, -0.67%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         and the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         are market-cap weighted. That means, companies with gargantuan values like Apple have an outsize influence on their movement. The S&P 500 was up 0.3%, while the Nasdaq rose by 0.9%. As an aside, it is important to note that Apple's $1 trillion value won't be officially realized until it closes at that level, for many market participants.
title: Apple hit $1 trillion market cap in intraday trade--but that milestone is doing little for the Dow

author: TomiKilgore
content:
As Apple Inc.'s stock 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AAPL, -0.30%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         pulls back from its intraday high of $207.05, which put the technology giant on track for a $1 trillion market capitalization, investors who bought at that price shouldn't feel too lonely. During a seven-second span, from 11:48:04 ET to 11:48:11, 49 trades went through at $207.05, for total volume of about 6,095 shares. At 11:48:04, about 3,400 shares over 33 trades went through at $207.05. At that price, the stock was up $5.55, or 2.75%, and Apple would have a market cap of $1.002 trillion. The stock has slipped to be up just 2.5% at $206.58, for a market cap of $997.7 billion. Apple is still well ahead of 2nd-place Amazon.com Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AMZN, -0.64%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         which currently has a market cap of $885.7 billion. Apple's stock has now run up 22% year to date, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 2.2%.
title: Nearly 50 trades in Apple's stock went through at the $1 trillion market-cap level

author: SarahToy
content:
Entertainment company Lions Gate Entertainment Corp

The companies also plan on leveraging UMPG's global roster of songwriters and catalog of songs for usage in Lions Gate's film, TV and digital content. author: EmilyBary
content:
Apple Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AAPL, -0.30%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         is on track to become the first U.S. company to reach a $1 trillion market capitalization, as its share price has crossed the $207.04 threshold in intraday trading on Thursday, with dozens of trades having been recorded at and above that level. The calculation is based on Apple's most up-to-date stated share count of 4.83 billion, as of July 20. The stock needs to close above the $207.04 mark for Apple to officially become the first to reach a $1 trillion capitalization.
title: Apple makes short-lived foray into trillion-dollar-market-cap territory

                                         are up 4.9% in Thursday morning trading after the company reported better-than-expected results for its latest quarter. Global Payments reported net income of $109.1 million, or 68 cents a share, up from $66.9 million, or 44 cents a share, a year earlier. The financial-technology company posted adjusted earnings per share of $1.29, ahead of the FactSet consensus estimate of $1.22 and up from 94 cents in the prior June quarter. Revenue rose to $982.5 million from $847.9 million a year ago and came in ahead of expectations for $967.9 million. The company also announced that it has agreed to acquire AdvancedMD, a software provider, for $700 million. Shares are up 18% so far this year, while the S&P 500

author: CiaraLinnane
content:
Red Robin Gourmet Burgers shares 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    RRGB, -2.33%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         slid 17% in early trade Thursday, after the company issued a profit warning for its fiscal second quarter, saying numbers would be "significantly lower than expected." Canaccord analysts downgraded the stock to hold from buy on the news and lowered their stock price target to $42 from $65. "Admittedly our recommendation and assumptions have not played out as we had expected," analyst Lynne Collier wrote in a note. "As we look forward, we think shares will continue to be range-bound in the near-to-intermediate term given same-store sales challenges and margin pressure." Collier said management's comment about service suggest labor cuts went too deep in a competitive market. "We have opportunities to improve our service execution, which has been impacted by the growing complexity of the multiple revenue streams within our four walls," Chief Executive Denny Post said in a statement. "We must also refresh our marketing message and move quickly on the digital guest experience." Raymond James downgraded the stock to market perform from outperform. Shares are down 34% in 2018, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 5%.
title: Red Robin Gourmet Burger slammed as analysts downgrade stock after profit warning

author: TonyaGarcia
content:
Red Robin Gourmet Burgers Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    RRGB, -2.33%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares plummeted nearly 24% in Thursday premarket trading after the restaurant chain gave a second-quarter profit warning, putting the company on track for the lowest open in 5 1/2 years. Red Robin expects to report a loss of 14 cents, driven by a 54-cents asset impairment charges, and adjusted earnings of 46 cents. Revenue is expected to total $315.4 million. The FactSet consensus as of July 31 had been for earnings of 65 cents and revenue of $323.6 million. Same-store sales are expected to decrease 2.6%, compared with a FactSet forecast for a 0.6% decline, as of July 31. "While we remain confident in the strategy that we have in place to address the shifts going on within casual dining, we simply didn't execute as well as we should have," said Denny Marie Post, Red Robin Gourmet Burgers, Inc., chief executive officer. The company has not seen the boost in dine-in traffic to offset the lower check average that is accompanying the Tavern Double Menu, Post said. Service has been impacted by the "growing complexity of multiple revenue streams" and the company needs to refresh its marketing and improve its digital experience. Red Robin will announce its second-quarter results after hours on August 21. Red Robin shares have fallen 18.7% for the year so far while the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 5.2% for the period.
title: Red Robin Gourmet Burgers shares plummet 24% after profit warning

author: TonyaGarcia
content:
Taco Bell said Thursday that it will add three "Cantina"-style restaurants in New York City by the end of the year. "Cantinas" have open kitchens, shareable tapas menus, local artwork and free wifi and outlets for customers. Taco Bell, part of the Yum Brands Inc.

                                         portfolio, plans to add 125 stores in New York City by 2022, part of a wider plan to open 1,000 restaurants in the U.S. in that time period. The brand plans to operate 9,000 restaurants around the world by 2022. Yum Brands shares are down 0.8% after reporting second-quarter earnings early Thursday. Food delivery platform Ele.me will pilot delivery service in Shanghai in September 2018, expanding to 30 cities and more than 2,000 stores by the end of the year. Starbucks is also partnering with Hema supermarkets to create Starbucks Delivery Kitchens that will fulfill orders. And Alibaba will create an online management hub that will operate not only in the Starbucks app but on Taobao, Alipay, Tmall and Koubei. author: JeffryBartash
content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) - U.S. factory orders advanced 0.7 in June, led by heavy machinery, trucks and passenger planes. Economists polled by MarketWatch has forecast a 0.7% increase. The originally reported 0.4% gain in May was unchanged, the government said Thursday.
title: U.S. factory orders in June jump 0.7%

author: TomiKilgore
content:
Sprouts Farmers Market Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SFM, +2.64%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         reported Thursday second-quarter earnings and revenue that matched expectations, and affirmed its sales outlook. The natural and organic grocer's stock was still inactive in premarket trade. Net income rose to $41.7 million, or 32 cents a share, from $41.0 million, or 29 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. The FactSet consensus for earnings per share was 32 cents. Revenue rose to $1.32 billion from $1.18 billion and same-store sales increased 2.0%, with both matching the FactSet consensus. Direct store expense increased 16% to $273 million, representing a rise to 20.7% of sales from 19.9%, due primarily to planned wage increases resulting from savings from recent tax legislation, as well as increased healthcare costs. The company affirmed its 2018 sales growth outlook of 10.5% to 11.5%, while bumping up its EPS outlook to $1.24 to $1.28 from $1.22 to $1.28. Separately, the company appointed Dave McGlinchey to the new executive role of chief merchandising officer. McGlinchey was previously senior vice president of merchandising services. The stock has tumbled 13% over the past three months, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 6.7%.
title: Sprouts Farmers Market reports in-line earnings and sales, names new CMO

content:

                                         shares rose nearly 6% in Thursday premarket trading after the online home retailer reported better-than-expected second-quarter revenue. Wayfair had a net loss of $100.7 million, or $1.13 per share, wider than the $38.9 million, or 45-cent loss, last year. Adjusted loss was 77 cents per share exceeding the FactSet consensus for a 73-cent loss. Revenue was $1.66 billion, up from $1.12 billion last year, and ahead of the $1.60 billion FactSet consensus. Wayfair said the quarter included its biggest revenue day ever with Way Day, a shopping event. The number of active customers increased 34% year-over-year to 12.8 million. Average order value was $254 compared with $258 last year. Wayfair shares have gained 33.6% for the year to date while the S&P 500 index

author: TomiKilgore
content:
Brookstone Co. Inc. said Thursday it has filed for bankruptcy, to facilitate the sale of the specialty travel and entertainment products retailer. The company said it has begun a process to close its remaining 101 mall stores, citing continued deterioration of retail mall traffic, while it will continue to operate its airport, e-commerce and wholesale businesses. "Today we have taken several important steps to restructure the business and ensure that Brookstone will be well-positioned to succeed for years to come," said Chief Executive Piau Phang Foo. The company said it has secured $30 million in post-petition financing to support its operations during the sale and restructuring process. The bankruptcy comes as the SPDR S&P Retail ETF 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    XRT, +0.06%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has rallied 20.3% over the past 12 months and the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 13.6%.
title: Brookstone files for bankruptcy, to close all remaining mall stores

author: CiaraLinnane
content:
Meal-kit provider Blue Apron Holdings Inc. shares 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    APRN, -3.57%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         slid 8% in premarket trade Thursday, after the company posted a wider loss for the second quarter as revenue fell short of estimates. The company said it had a net loss of $32.8 million, or 17 cents a share, in the second quarter, compared with a loss of $31.6 million, or 47 cents a share, posted in the year-earlier period. Revenue fell 25% to $179.6 million. The FactSet consensus was for a loss per share of 17 cents and revenue of $188 million. Marketing expenses rose to $34.6 million, equal to 19.3% of revenue from 14.5% a year ago. Cost of goods sold improved 400 basis points to 64.7% from 68.7%. "With fulfillment center operations strengthening, we are increasing focus on the priorities we expect will propel revenue performance and return the business to a growth trajectory, including evolving and expanding our product portfolio, enhancing our overall customer experience, and launching our retail and on-demand offerings," Chief Executive Brad Dickerson said in a statement. Revenue was dented by the company's decision to prioritize operational stability and build a foundation for growth, he said. The number of customers fell 24% from a year ago, while average revenue per customer edged down to $250 from $251. Orders fell to 3.12 million from 4.03 million a year ago. Shares rose 1.7% in premarket trade, but are down 40% in 2018, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 5%.
title: UPDATE: Blue Apron shares slide 8% premarket after loss widens and revenue falls 25%

The company said the jump was due to lower restructuring charges, favorable adjustments, and a one-time gain from a West Africa transaction. Adjusted EPS was $1.14, beating the $1.05 FactSet consensus. Sales were $3.36 billion up from $3.18 billion, ahead of the $3.30 billion FactSet guidance. Sales in North America slipped as the snacks and morning foods segments declined. Europe, Latin America and Asia Pacific reported sales growth. author: EmilyBary
content:
Shares of TripAdvisor Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    TRIP, -1.25%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         are down more than 11% in premarket trading Thursday after the company reported a slight revenue miss and beat earnings expectations by a cent. TripAdvisor's hotel business performed better than expectations, while its non-hotel business fell short. "Expectations had risen in recent months, as had optimism around non-hotel growth, so these results will likely be seen as somewhat 'lackluster' by some investors," wrote Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson, who raised his price target to $50 from $49 but kept his neutral rating. Jefferies analyst Brent Thill was less upbeat, writing that TripAdvisor "remains a 'transition' story with a turnaround that gets constantly pushed further into the future." He has an underperform rating and $31 target on the stock. Shares were up 67% so far in 2018, as of Wednesday's close, while the S&P 500

author: EmmaCourt
content:
Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    RCL, -0.47%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares dropped 2.3% in Thursday premarket trade after the company reported a second-quarter revenue miss and profit beat. Earnings for the latest quarter rose to $466.3 million, or $2.19 per share, from $369.5 million, or $1.71 per share in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings-per-share were $2.27, compared with the FactSet consensus of $2.01. Revenue rose to $2.338 billion from $2.195 billion, below the FactSet consensus of $2.343 billion. The latest results reflect the negative impact of foreign exchange and fuel rates, but "we are tickled pink that our business continues to excel and overcome these headwinds," said Chief Executive Richard Fain. Royal Caribbean continues to expect 2018 adjusted EPS of $8.70 to $8.90 per share, which includes a negative impact of 35 cents connected to currency and fuel and 6 cents in additional interest expense related to the Silversea purchase. Company shares have lifted 2.6% over the last three months, compared with a 6.7% rise in the S&P 500

title: Royal Caribbean stock drops 2% on Q2 revenue miss

Shares of DowDuPont Inc.

Net income was $1.77 billion, or 76 cents a share, compared with $1.32 billion, or $1.07 a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, adjusted earnings per share came to $1.37, above the FactSet consensus of $1.29. Revenue increased 17% to $24.25 billion, beating the FactSet consensus of $23.68 billion, as agriculture sales rose 25%, materials science sales grew 18% and specialty products sales increased 10%. The company said it expects third-quarter sales to be "up more than 10%" from a year ago, while the FactSet consensus of $19.43 billion implies 6.3% growth. The stock has lost 4.6% year to date, while the Dow has gained 2.5%.

author: WilliamL.Watts
content: The Bank of England on Thursday, as expected, raised its bank rate by 25 basis points, or a quarter of a percentage point, to 0.75%. The nine-member Monetary Policy Committee voted unanimously for the hike. "Since the May Inflation Report, the near-term outlook has evolved broadly in line with the MPC's expectations," the committee said in a statement. "Recent data appear to confirm that the dip in output in the first quarter was temporary, with momentum recovering in the second quarter. The labor market has continued to tighten and unit labor cost growth has firmed." In a nod to difficult Brexit negotiations, the MPC said it "continues to recognize that the economic outlook could be influenced significantly by the response of households, businesses and financial markets to developments related to the process of EU withdrawal.:
title: Bank of England raises key lending rate to 0.75%

                                         said Thursday it had a net loss of $37 million, or 9 cents a share, in the second quarter, narrower than the loss of $46 millin, or 12 cents a share, posted in the year-earlier period. Adjusted per-share loss came to 3 cents a share, wider than the FactSet consensus for breakeven. Revenue fell 3% to $$1.352 billion from $1.395 billion, below the FactSet consensus of $1.398 billion. Chief Executive Jan Zijderveld said he was encouraged by revenue growth in three of the company's top markets. "However, we are not yet satisfied with the overall operating results of the quarter," he said. The company is now focused on its representative experience and is planning enhanced training and new sales incentives. "We will support our second half global launches with an additional $30 million of advertising and marketing spend," he said. "And, finally, we are placing digital at the center of all actions to drive our future progress, enhancing our digital and e-commerce capabilities through initiatives such as our new mobile e-brochure, which is locally customizable and distributed via social media." Shares were not yet active premarket, but have fallen 24.2% in 2018, while the S&P 500

                                         priced its initial public offering at $17 a share Wednesday evening, the middle of its proposed range. The giant real-estate services firm plans to sell at least 45 million shares at that price, which would bring in at least $765 million at a valuation of about $3.13 billion.                                          will bring in less money than it hoped in an initial public offering, announcing a price of $15 a share Wednesday evening. The maker of high-end speakers had hoped to price shares at $17 to $19 apiece, according to previous filings, but said Wednesday evening that it would instead sell 13.89 million shares at a lower price. At that price, Sonos will bring in at least $208 million at a valuation of nearly $1.5 billion. author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
Tesla Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    TSLA, +0.86%
revealed in its earnings conference call Wednesday that it has developed its own hardware to handle self-driving features in its cars. Tesla had been relying on hardware from Nvidia Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NVDA, -0.65%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         but Chief Executive Elon Musk said Wednesday that he wanted to move away from the GPUs Nvidia offers. "I'm a big fan of Nvidia, they do great stuff, but ... the transfer between the GPU and CPU ends up being what constrains the system," Musk said in announcing the new chips, which he said had been in development for more than two years. "Probably time to let the cat out of the bag, because that cat's going to come out of the bag anyway," Musk said. Nvidia Chief Executive Jensen Huangtold MarketWatch in May that Tesla's business was not a material concern as the Model 3 rollout faced delays. "The volume from Tesla is not that high, there is no material difference one way or the other," Huang said then. Nvidia shares dipped about 0.3% after the announcement was made, while Tesla shares were trading 10% higher in after-hours trading.
title: Tesla reveals new chips for self-driving cars

author: SteveGoldstein
content: Special Counsel Robert Mueller wants to ask President Donald Trump about obstruction of justice, ABC News reported, citing sources close to the White House. That news was the genesis for Trump's tweets which included the request for his attorney general, Jeff Sessions, to end the probe, the report said. The president learned within the last day that the special counsel would like to ask questions both orally and written, the report said.
title: Mueller wants to ask Trump about obstruction of justice, ABC reports

content:

                                         shares rallied in the extended session Wednesday after the cybersecurity company's quarterly results and outlook topped Wall Street estimates. Fortinet shares surged 10% after hours, following a 2.7% rise to finish the regular session at $64.60. The company reported second-quarter net income of $49.3 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with $23 million, or 13 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings were 41 cents a share. Revenue rose to $441.3 million from $363.5 million in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated 35 cents a share on revenue of $425.4 million. Second-quarter billings were $513.4 million, while analysts were looking for $490.9 million. Fortinet estimates adjusted earnings of 41 cents to 43 cents a share on revenue of $445 million to $455 million for the third quarter, and $1.63 to $1.67 a share on revenue of $1.77 billion to $1.79 billion for the year. Analysts expect earnings of 39 cents a share on revenue of $431.2 million for the third quarter, and $1.54 a share on revenue of $1.73 billion for the year.
title: Fortinet shares surge 10% as earnings, outlook top Street view

Tesla said it lost $718 million, or $4.22, in the quarter, compared with $336 million, or $2.04 a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted for one-time items, Tesla lost $520 million, or $3.06 a share, compared with $220 million, or $1.33 a share, a year ago. Revenue rose to $4 billion from $2.77 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected adjusted earnings of $2.88 a share on sales of $3.99 billion. Tesla said it aims to produce 6,000 Model 3 sedans a week by late August, and also kept intact its target of delivering 100,000 Model S and Model X vehicles this year. Shares ended the regular trading day up 0.9%.

author: CiaraLinnane
content:
The U.S. Justice Department said Wednesday that Wells Fargo & Co.

                                         has agreed to pay $2.09 billion in a settlement over the sale of crisis-era mortgage loans. The bank originated and sold residential mortgage loans that it knew contained misstated income information and fell short of quality standards, said the DoJ. "Investors, including federally insured financial institutions, suffered billions of dollars in losses from investing in residential mortgage-backed securities (RMBS) containing loans originated by Wells Fargo," said the statement. The fine is the latest for the troubled bank, which is still struggling to recover from a series of scandals involving the creation of unauthorized accounts and imposition of other products and fees on unsuspecting customers. the San Francisco-based bank disclosed a $619 million charge in its second-quarter earnings to refund customers who were overcharged in its foreign exchange, wealth-management and automotive and mortgage lending units. Wells Fargo shares were up 0.2% in afternoon trade, but are down 5% in 2018, while the S&P 500

author: AnnekenTappe
content:
The U.S. Dollar retraced some of its gains on Wednesday, after the Federal Reserve gave its August policy update. The central bank left interest rates unchanged -- as expected -- and upgraded the U.S. economic expansion to "strong" from "solid." The Fed also commented on decent job gains in recent months in recent months in the accompanying statement. The next data point due to confirm this statement are July non-farm payrolls due Friday. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates next at its September meeting, with Fed funds futures showing a 90% chance of a rate hike. It would be the eighth raise since late 2015. The ICE U.S. Dollar Index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DXY, +1.38%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         pared some of its advances and was last up 0.1% at 94.589, compared with 0.2% before the announcement.
title: Dollar pares some gains after Fed update on economy

author: JeffryBartash
content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) - The Federal Reserve voted unamimously to leave a key U.S. interest rate unchanged, but the central bank also signaled more rates hikes are coming by upgrading its view of the economy to "strong" from "solid." In a statement, the Fed on Wednesday said the economy "has been rising at a strong rate." The central bank had used the word "solid" in June. The Fed also said both consumer spending and business investment "have grown strongly." Inflation, for its part, "remained near 2%,' the Fed noted after the end of its two-day meeting in Washington. The central bank has previously signaled it would raise rates twice more in 2018 by a quarter-point, with the next one widely expected in September. By the end of 2018 the Fed expects to lift its benchmark rate to an average of 2.4% from the current range of 1.75% to 2%.
title: FOMC stands pat on interest rates, calls economy 'strong'

author: RobertSchroeder
content: The Trump administration announced sanctions Wednesday on Turkey's justice and interior ministers over that country's detention of an American pastor. President Donald Trump raised the prospect of sanctions last week over the detainment of Pastor Andrew Brunson, who denies charges of aiding a failed coup. White House press secretary Sarah Sanders said any property of the Turkish officials that is within U.S. jurisdiction is frozen.
title: U.S. sanctions Turkey's justice, interior ministers over pastor's detention

author: SteveGoldstein
content: White House press secretary Sarah Sanders said there will be an announcement made on Chinese tariffs on Wednesday, amid reports the U.S. will increase the rate on proposed $200 billion tariffs to 25% from 10%.
title: White House says there will be an announcement on Chinese tariffs on Wednesday

The fast-casual chain offered free guacamole with an online or in-app purchase of an entree, using the coupon code "avocado." The company said digital sales were up nearly 60%, also giving the company its biggest summer sales day ever. Chipotle didn't give dollar figures.                                          acquisition that hasn't made money, plans to start making money next year, the company said Wednesday. WhatsApp will start selling ads it its Status feature, which is similar to Instagram's Stories feature, which already shows ads. Facebook's ad technology will power the new ad units in WhatsApp, The Wall Street Journal reported. WhatsApp also said that it plans to start charging big companies to communicate with their customers, billing companies between half a penny and 9 cents per message delivered, depending on the country. A small percentage of the 60 billion messages WhatsApp users exchange are between companies and their customers. WhatsApp currently boasts about 1.5 billion accounts. Facebook stock has fallen 0.6% in mid-afternoon trading, and roughly 20% since its earnings report last week disappointed investors. author: ClaudiaAssis
content:
Hedge fund Greenlight Capital, managed by David Einhorn, lashed out at several companies in its letter to investors late Tuesday, but Greenlight and Einhorn got personal with Tesla Inc.

                                         According to the letter, Einhorn "is happy that his Model S lease ended (there were growing problems with the touchscreen and the power windows" and happy to switch to an electric Jaguar. Next year will be "a very challenging" year for Tesla, and the letter continued on a more personal tone saying that Tesla Chief Executive Elon Musk "appears erratic and desperate." Replying to a tweet about Einhorn's lapsed lease, Musk said in the small hours of Wednesday that he'd send Einhorn "a box of short shorts to comfort him through this difficult time."
title: Musk, Einhorn exchange barbs after hedge-fund manager lashes out at Tesla

The company reported a loss of $5.9 million in the latest quarter, or a loss of 7 cents per share, after a loss of $60.0 million, or a loss of 68 cents per share in the year-earlier period. The FactSet adjusted earnings-per-share consensus was a loss of 17 cents. Revenue rose to $96.9 million from $6.3 million, compared with the FactSet consensus of $83.7 million. The revenue beat was made possible by what Chief Executive Kevin Gorman described as the "continued adoption of Ingrezza by physicians and patients," referring to its drug for the rare condition tardive dyskinesia, whichcame to market last year. The company's endometriosis therapy, Orilissa, was also recently approved by the Food and Drug Administration. Neurocrine said that it had $841.3 million in assets, including cash, investments and about $800 million in receivables, as of June 30. Neurocrine shares have surged more than 30% over the last three months, compared with a 6% rise in the S&P 500

author: MyraP.Saefong
content:
Oil prices continued to trade lower Wednesday after the Energy Information Administration reported that domestic crude supplies rose by 3.8 million barrels for the week ended July 27. Analysts surveyed by S&P Global Platts had forecast a fall of 2.4 million barrels, while the American Petroleum Institute on Tuesday reported a rise of 5.6 million barrels, according to sources. Gasoline stockpiles declined by 2.5 million barrels for the week, while distillate stockpiles rose 3 million barrels, according to the EIA. The S&P Global Platts survey forecast a supply decrease of 1.5 million barrels for gasoline, along with a climb of 560,000 barrels for distillate stocks. author: SteveGoldstein
content: Construction spending fell 1.1% in June, the Commerce Department said, as both residential and nonresidential spending dropped. Even with the decline, spending has climbed 6.1% over the last 12 months. May's growth rate was revised to show a 1.3% increase instead of a previously reported 0.4% gain. The June seasonally adjusted annual level of $1.32 trillion was above the initially reported May reading of $1.31 trillion.
title: Construction spending drops in June after upward revision

author: MarkDeCambre
content:
The 10-year Treasury note touched a psychologically significant level at 3% for the first time since mid June. The 10-year near note 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    TMUBMUSD10Y, -0.54%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         stood at 3.002%, most recently. That's a rate it hasn't hit since June 13. The benchmark note, used to price all manner of debt, including home and car loans, as well as corporate debt, has at times created friction in equity markets, when it rises, because advancing borrowing costs for U.S. corporations can erode revenues. However, a move toward 3% comes after the U.S. economy posted a 4.1% annual rate of expansion for the second quarter and as major companies have booked relatively strong quarterly reports, which may, in theory, help to mute the effects of rising rates. The Dow Jones Industrial Average

                                    SPX, -0.71%
ESU8, -0.46%

                                         slumped 3% in premarket trade Wednesday, after the beer brewer beat second-quarter earnings and revenue expectations, but suffered a fourth-straight quarter of declines in U.S. sales. Net income rose 29% from a year ago to $424.1 million, or $1.96 a share, while adjusted earnings per share of $1.88 beat the FactSet consensus of $1.83. Revenue slipped 0.2% to $3.085 billion, just above the FactSet consensus of $3.081 billion. U.S. sales fell 3.1% to $2.07 billion and Canada sales declined 2.55 to $397.4 million, while Europe sales grew 11.7% to $586.1 million and international sales rose 4.3% to $67.9 million. U.S. brand volume declined 4.8%, due primarily to lower volume in the Premium Light segment. Chief Executive Mark Hunter said the company was "aggressively addressing our volume performance in North America." The stock has dropped 25% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500

                                         has gained 14%.

author: CiaraLinnane
content:
J.M. Smucker Co. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SJM, +0.12%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         said Wednesday it has signed renewable energy purchase agreement with Lincoln Clean energy for 60 megawatts of the power produced at the Plum Creek Wind Project in Wayne County, Nebraska. The owner of brands including Folgers, Smucker's and Cafe Bustelo coffee, as well as Dunkin' Donuts, Rachel Ray and Natural Balance, said that from 2020, it expects wind power from Plum Creek to account for about half of its total electricity use. In 2017, electricity accounted for more than half of the company's greenhouse gas emissions. "This agreement will not only reduce our carbon footprint, but will also allow us to make a lasting contribution to our nation's renewable energy capacity," Julia Sabin, vice president of government relations and corporate sustainability said in a statement. Shares were not yet active premarket, but have fallen 11% in 2018, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 5%.
title: J.M. Smucker aims to have half its power use come from wind energy by 2020

                                         surged 4% in premarket trade Wednesday, after a Wall Street Journal report that activist investor Third Point LLC has build a stake worth more than $300 million. The stake amounts to more than 2.5% of the company's stock, said the paper, which cited a person familiar with the matter. Third Point founder Daniel Loeb has spoken to Campbell's interim CEO Keith McLouglin about possible courses of action for the troubled food company, said the paper. Campbell is currently in the midst of a review of its strategic and operating plans that includes a review of its portfolio of products, which include Prego sauces, Snyder's Lance snacks and Bolthouse Farms. In May, the company announced the abrupt departure of Chief Executive Denise Morrison after three straight years of declining sales. Shares have fallen 15% in 2018, while the S&P 500

author: TomiKilgore
content:
Shares of Diebold Nixdorf Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DBD, -16.84%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         plummeted 26% in premarket track, putting them on track to open at a 27-year low, after the provider of software services to the financial and retail sectors reported a surprise second-quarter loss and said it looked to amend credit agreements as a results of a lowered outlook. The net loss widened to $138.5 million, or $1.82 a share, from $30.6 million, or 41 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, the adjusted loss was 21 cents, compared with the FactSet consensus for a profit of a penny. Revenue fell 2.5% to $1.11 billion, above the FactSet consensus of $1.09 billion, as increases in Americas banking and retail revenue offset a decline in Eurasia banking revenue. The company expects 2018 revenue of about $4.5 billion, compared with a previous outlook of $4.5 billion to $4.7 billion, and cut its adjusted EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) guidance range to $280 million to $320 million from $380 million to $410 million. "While we are currently in compliance with our debt covenants, we have engaged our principal lenders to amend out credit agreement as a result of our revised outlook," said Chief Financial Officer Christopher Chapman. The stock had plunged 26% over the past three months through Tuesday, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         had gained 6.1%.
title: Diebold Nixdorf's stock plummets toward 27-year low after surprise loss, credit agreement amendment

                                         shares leaped nearly 16% in Wednesday premarket trading after the sparkling water maker reported second-quarter earnings that beat expectations and raised its guidance. Net income totaled $26.1 million, or $1.14 per share, up from $14.4 million, or 64 cents per share, for the same period last year. Revenue totaled $171.5 million, up from $130.6 million last year. The FactSet consensus was for EPS of 73 cents and sales of $149.0 million. Sales of sparkling water makers rose 22% for the quarter, and gas refill units were up 17% to a record 9.7 million in sales, according to a statement from Daniel Birnbaum, chief executive of the company. SodaStream expects full-year revenue to increase 23% from 2017, up from previous 15% growth. And earnings are expected to grow 31%, up from previous guidance of 8% growth. The FactSet consensus is for revenue of $623.2 million, up 12.8% year-over year, and EPS of $3.56, 7.6% from last year. SodaStream shares have gained more than 24% for the year to date, outpacing the S&P 500 index

Additional markets will offer the service in the coming months. To start, Kroger Ship will offer 4,500 products from the Our Brands line and more than 50,000 other grocery and household items. Orders over $35 will be shipped for free, otherwise there's a $4.99 shipping charge that will be applied after the launch phase. There is also a 15% off coupon available for one-time use in the initial phase.                                          reported second-quarter net income of $19 million, or $1.39 a share, compared with $1.04 billion, or $4.46 a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, such as a $790 million loss on the sale of its KMG America Corp. subsidiary, adjusted earnings per share rose to $3.96 from $3.49, beating the FactSet consensus of $3.77. Total revenue increased 5.4% to $14.26 billion, above the FactSet consensus of $14.11 billion, as premiums grew 3.9% to $13.71 billion to beat expectations of $13.48 billion. The health care company raised its 2018 adjusted EPS guidance to $14.15 from a previous range of $13.70 to $14.10. The revenue outlook was nudged up to $55.9 billion to $56.5 billion from $55.8 billion to $56.4 billion. The stock, which was still inactive in premarket trade, has run up 27% year to date, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 5.3%.
title: Humana beats earnings expectations, raises outlook

author: KarenFriar
content: China plans to retaliate if the U.S. steps up its use of tariffs to put pressure on Beijing in the dispute over trade, Reuters reported Wednesday. The comments from China's Foreign Ministry come after advisers urged President Donald Trump to sharply increase the level of tariffs proposed for $200 billion in Chinese imports, to as high as 25%, compared with the original proposal of 10%. Geng Shuang, a spokesman for the Chinese ministry, told reporters that the U.S. pressure on trade won't work and that Beijing has always upheld using dialogue to resolve trade issues, Reuters reported.
title: China says U.S. tariff pressure won't work, will retaliate: Reuters

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
Synaptics Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SYNA, -11.38%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares plunged in late trading Tuesday after the company's merger talks with Dialog Semiconductor PLC

                                         fell apart. Synaptics stock was down 13.6% at the end of the extended session, after reports that Dialog had called off talks to acquire Synaptics. Synaptics confirmed the end of discussions in a press release later Tuesday evening. "Synaptics is a global leader and technology innovator in multiple high growth markets, and interest by a number of industry players underscores the tremendous value inherent to our company," Chief Executive Rick Bergman said in the release. Synaptics shares soared last month after talks between the companies were first reported.

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
Apple Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AAPL, -0.30%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         fell from the top two global smartphone makers for the first time in eight years during the second quarter, International Data Corp. reported Tuesday. IDC said Apple's market share grew from 11.8% to 12.1% in the past year, but it was leapfrogged by Chinese manufacturer Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd., which grew from 11% to 15.8%, topped only by Samsung Electronics Co. Ltd. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    005930, -0.77%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         which fell from 22.9% to 20.9%. "The continued growth of Huawei is impressive, to say the least, as is its ability to move into markets where, until recently, the brand was largely unknown," IDC's Ryan Reith said in Tuesday's announcement. "It is worth noting that Apple moved into the top position each of the last two holiday quarters following its product refresh, so it's likely we'll see continued movement among the top ranked companies in 2018 and beyond." Overall, smartphone shipments declined 1.8% from the year before, the third straight quarter of declines, IDC reported. IDC released the report as Apple executives were discussing fiscal third-quarter earnings, which beat expectations thanks to higher average selling prices for Apple's premium smartphones, even as unit sales came in lower than expected.
title: Apple falls behind Huawei in smartphone market share: IDC

SendGrid shares surged 7.7% after hours. The company reported a second-quarter loss of $310,000, or a penny a share, compared with a loss of $1.3 million, or 17 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings were 5 cents a share. Revenue rose to $35.7 million from $27 million in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated a penny a share on revenue of $34.4 million. SendGrid estimates revenue of $35.9 million to $36.1 million for the third quarter, and $142.5 million to $144 million for the year. Analysts expect revenue of $35.3 million for the third quarter and $141.7 million for the year. SendGrid shares closed Tuesday up 6.5% for the year at $25.53, or 60% above their November IPO price.

author: MyraP.Saefong
content:
The American Petroleum Institute reported Tuesday that U.S. crude supplies rose by 5.6 million barrels for the week ended July 27, according to sources. The API data also showed supplies of gasoline fell by 791,000 barrels, while distillate stockpiles added 2.9 million barrels, sources said. Supply data from the Energy Information Administration will be released Wednesday. Analysts polled by S&P Global Platts expect the EIA to report a fall of 2.4 million barrels in crude supplies. They also forecast a supply decline of 1.5 million barrels for gasoline and an increase of 560,000 barrels for distillates. September crude

Big 5 said it lost $200,000, or a penny a share, in the quarter, versus a net income $2.8 million, or 13 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales fell to $240 million, compared with $243.7 million a year ago. Same-store sales fell 2.1% in the quarter, versus a 0.9% increase in same-store sales a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet expected Big 5 to post GAAP and adjusted earnings of 11 cents a share on sales of $247 million in the quarter. "Much of the softness resulted from weak sales of camping and water sports products, which were negatively impacted by unfavorable weather conditions in key markets around the high-volume selling periods of Memorial Day, Father's Day and the start of summer," Big 5 said in a statement.
title: Big 5 shares tank on surprise quarterly loss, sales miss

author: SteveGoldstein
content: The U.S. has made little progress in resolving its trade dispute with China, The Wall Street Journal reported. The two sides have agreed that their initial offers weren't a solid base for further negotiations, the report said, citing a U.S. business member tracking the talks. Talks between Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Chinese envoy Liu He remain at a very early stage, the report said. The administration believes it strengthened its hand last week with a tentative trade accord with the European Union, the report added.
title: U.S. has made little progress in China talks: WSJ

Prices on Tuesday saw pressure as concerns about Iranian oil eased back, even as President Donald Trump’s willingness to meet Iran’s president was not expected to influence U.S. sanctions on Iranian oil, which are set to begin in November.
