author: TomiKilgore
content:
Shares of Chevron Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    CVX, +0.66%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shed 2.6% in premarket trade Friday, after the oil giant reported second-quarter earnings and revenue that missed expectations, as a big jump in oil prices was offset by a drop in natural gas prices. Net income rose to $3.41 billion, or $1.78 a shares, from $1.45 billion, or 77 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. The results included a $270 million receivable write down, which based on 1.919 billion weighted-average diluted shares outstanding represents 14 cents a share. The FactSet consensus for earnings per share was $2.09. Total revenue grew to $42.24 billion from $34.48 billion, well below the FactSet consensus of $45.65 billion. Net oil-equivalent production increased to 2.83 million barrels per day from 2.78 million barrels per day, missind the FactSet consensus of 2.85 million barrels per day. Average sales price per barrel of crude oil and natural gas liquids increased to $59 from $41, while average price of natural gas fell to $1.61 per thousand cubic feet from $2.32. The stock has shed 1% year to date through Thursday, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 3.3%.
title: Chevron's stock drops after earnings and revenue miss

author: AnnekenTappe
content:
The U.S. dollar briefly pared some of its gains after U.S. GDP data revealed that the U.S. economy expanded 4.1%--less than expected--between April and June. Economists polled by MarketWatch had forecasted 4.2%, while some market participants expected as much 5% for the second quarter of the year. But despite the cooler-than-expected read, the economy was still expanding at a strong pace, which may keep intact market expectations for future interest-rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The next hike is expected for September. The ICE U.S. Dollar Index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DXY, +1.36%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         was last 0.1% higher at 94.829, around the same level it was at prior to the data release The greenback's main rivals--the euro 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    EURUSD, -0.2804%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                        --remained in modestly negative territory, last buying $1.1629.
title: U.S. dollar holds modest gain after GDP data

author: MarketWatch
content:
U.S. stock-index futures turned slightly lower after a highly anticipated reading on economic growth came in below consensus forecasts of economists surveyed by MarketWatch. The U.S. economy expanded at a 4.1% rate in the second quarter, versus expectations of a 4.2% pace. author: GregRobb
content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) - U.S. economic growth accelerated to an annual rate of 4.1% in the second quarter, compared with a revised 2.2% in the first quarter, the Commerce Department said Friday. This is the fastest rate of growth in almost four years. The second quarter gain was close to the 4.2% rate economists surveyed by MarketWatch had forecast. The acceleration of real gross domestic product in the second quarter reflected a jump in consumer and government spending. The trade sector boosted GDP but this was offset by a downturn in inventory investment. Real final sales for domestic purchasers, which excludes trade and inventories, rose 3.9% in the second quarter after a 1.9% gain in the prior quarter.
title: U.S. second-quarter GDP accelerates to 4.1% annual rate

author: TomiKilgore
content:
Wall Street analysts rushed to raise their stock price targets on Amazon.com Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AMZN, -0.64%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         after the e-commerce giant reported blowout second-quarter results, and now project the company to be the first to crack the $1 trillion market-capitalization mark. The average price target of the 48 analysts surveyed by FactSet increased to $2,076.83, up from $1,892.66 at the end of June. With 487.74 million shares outstanding, that would peg Amazon's market cap at $1.01 trillion. The average price target for Apple Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AAPL, -0.30%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         is $201.79, which would represent a market cap of $991.87 billion, based on 4.915 billion shares outstanding as of April 20. Apple's share count will be updated after it reports results on July 31, and is likely to be lower than the April 20 total because of share buybacks, which would lower the market-cap outlook. Amazon's stock surged 4.3% in premarket trade after the company reported results after Thursday's close. It has run up 15.0% over the past three months through Thursday, while Apple shares have rallied 19.7% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 5.0%.
title: Analysts now project Amazon to top $1 trillion in market cap, ahead of Apple

Revenue rose to $73.501 billion from $58.077 billion. The FactSet consensus was for EPS of $1.27 and revenue of $74.153 billion. The numbers "were primarily impacted by significant scheduled maintenance undertaken to support operational integrity," chief Executive Darren Woods said in a statement. "In addition, while we were pleased with the return of full production following the PNG earthquake, extended recoveries from first quarter operational incidents in the Downstream were disappointing. However, good progress was made during the second quarter in fully recovering from these incidents." author: TomiKilgore
content:
Shares of Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    GT, -1.98%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         dropped 1.2% toward a near 4-year low in premarket trade Friday, after the tire maker beat second-quarter profit expectations but sales came up a bit shy, and gave a downbeat outlook. Net income rose to $157 million, or 65 cents a share, from $147 million, or 58 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, adjusted earnings per share came to 62 cents, above the FactSet consensus of 59 cents. Revenue grew 4% to $3.84 billion from $3.69 billion, compared with the FactSet consensus of $3.85 billion. Tire unit volume increased 4% to 39.0 million. The company cut its 2018 segment operating income guidance range to $1.45 billion to $1.50 billion from the $1.8 billion-to-$1.9 billion range provided in April, citing expectations that raw materials costs will increase $130 million in the second half of the year, a $60 million unfavorable swing in foreign currency translation resulting from a strong U.S. dollar and a $70 million headwind from "softening" market conditions in China. The stock, on track to open at the lowest level since October 2014, had tumbled 34.5% year to date through Thursday, while the S&P 500

                                         are down 22% in premarket trading after the company delivered a disappointing third-quarter forecast. J.P. Morgan analyst Sterling Auty downgraded the stock to neutral from overweight following the earnings report. "The issues in the collaboration segment of the business, the largest portion of revenue at 57%, are causing management to lower the full-year outlook and likely will place the stock in the penalty box as changes will take a couple of quarters to get worked out," he wrote. "LogMeIn's valuation on a cash flow basis appears to be a sizable discount, but investors will likely question the ability to deliver the results in the near-term keeping a lid on shares, especially given management commentary about competition and prices." Auty also discussed competitive pressures, which he said will remain a concern for investors until the company sees improvement in its collaboration business. LogMeIn makes tools that facilitate remote connectivity. Adjusted per-share earnings came to 77 cents, matching the FactSet consensus. Sales rose to $3.886 billion from $3.826 billion, below the FactSet consensus of $3.916 billion. The company is now expecting a low-single-digit net sales increase in 2018 and double-digit growth in EPS. author: MikeMurphy
content: Michael Cohen, President Donald Trump's former personal attorney, claims Trump knew in advance about a summer 2016 meeting at Trump Tower between top campaign staffers, including his son, Donald Trump Jr., and Russians said to be offering damaging information on Hillary Clinton, according to a CNN report late Thursday. Sources told CNN that Cohen was willing to confirm as much to special counsel Robert Mueller. Trump has repeatedly denied knowing about the meeting, but sources reportedly told CNN that Cohen was in the room with Trump when he was told about it, and approved the meeting ahead of time. The Mueller investigation has been looking into the meeting as possible evidence of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia.
title: Cohen claims Trump approved 2016 Trump Tower meeting with Russians: report

author: GregRobb
content: The Chinese economy is at a "historic juncture" having to move from "high speed" growth to "high quality" growth, and how this shift is carried through will determine the country's development path for decades to come, the staff of the International Monetary Fund said in a report released Thursday. There are tensions in the government's strategy between, on the one hand, allowing market forces a decisive role and the pervasive role of the state, the report said. Relatively restrictive trade-and-investment regime in some areas and still unsustainable debt growth are other key challenges. To succeed, China must rein in credit growth, increase the role of market forces, and foster openness, the staff said. The risks are to the downside, including from the ongoing trade dispute with the U.S.
title: China is at a 'historic juncture,' with outcome uncertain: IMF staff report

author: AaronHankin
content: The Securities and Exchange Commission Thursday rejected a bid by Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss for the first-ever, bitcoin-related exchange-traded-fund. The SEC rejection marks another attempt by the duo to create the first bitcoin-pegged ETF that will pass muster with regulators. The news pushed the price of bitcoin [s:btcusd], the world's biggest digital currency lower, with a single coin last trading at $8,113.16, down 0.9% since 5 p.m. Wednesday on the Kraken Exchange. The SEC is yet to approve a digital-currency-related ETF citing concerns around liquidity and custody-the security and holding of the underlying digital asset. There remains at least two more proposals for a bitcoin ETF under review by the SEC, including one by Bitwise Asset Management and the joint proposal by VanEck and SolidX.
title: Winklevoss bitcoin ETF rejected by SEC

author: ClaudiaAssis
content:
Shares of LogMeIn Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    LOGM, -2.07%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         fell nearly 15% late Thursday after the software and cloud-computing company reported mixed second-quarter results and posted third-quarter and full-year guidance below expectations. LogMeIn said it earned $6.6 million, or 12 cents a share, in the quarter, compared with $15 million, or 28 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted for one-time items, the company earned $69.8 million, or $1.32 a share, compared with $1.01 a share a year ago. Sales rose to $306 million, compared with $257 million a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected the company to report adjusted earnings of $1.25 a share on sales of $305 million. LogMeIn said it expects revenue in a range between $302 million and $304 million in the third quarter, and adjusted net income between $1.33 and $1.35 a share in the quarter. The analysts surveyed by FactSet expect adjusted earnings of $1.36 a share in the quarter. For fiscal 2018, the company guided for revenue between $1.185 billion and $1.195 billion, and adjusted net income between $5.17 and $5.26 a share. FactSet has consensus adjusted EPS of $5.27 for the year. Shares of LogMeIn ended the regular trading day down 3.6%.
title: Shares of LogMeIn tank 15% on mixed company results, lower guidance

Analysts had been expecting $2.81 in earnings per share, according to FactSet. Revenue rose to $289.6 million from $274.7 million in the year-earlier period. author: RobertSchroeder
content: Speaking in Illinois, President Donald Trump said Thursday he thinks gross domestic product numbers set to be released Friday will be "terrific." Trump said he doesn't know what the second-quarter number will be, but said if it has a "four" in front of it, "we're happy." Economists polled by MarketWatch are predicting growth of 4.2%.
title: Trump says he thinks GDP will be 'terrific,' but doesn't know number

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
Atlassian Corp. PLC 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    TEAM, -0.31%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has decided to stop competing with Slack and team up with the software startup, selling intellectual property for its competing software offerings to Slack and investing in the company. Atlassian shares jumped more than 16% in after-hours trading to prices that would easily top record highs in regular trading. Atlassian launched a new Slack competitor called Stride last year, and already had another messaging program called Hipchat. Those services will be discontinued, and customers will be migrated to Slack, Atlassian said in its announcement. "We are excited to join forces with Slack to target the immense markets for team collaboration and communications," Mike Cannon-Brookes, Atlassian co-CEO and co-founder, said in Thursday's news release. Atlassian also reported fourth-quarter earnings that beat analyst expectations, reporting adjusted earnings of 13 cents a share on sales of $243.8 million against average analyst expectations of 12 cents a share on revenue of $233.4 million, according to FactSet. Atlassian shares rose more than 16% in late trading after closing with a 0.3% decline at $66.83; shares have never traded for more than $68.98 in a regular session, but were going for more than $77 in after-hours action. The stock has gained 46.8% so far this year, while the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 6.5%.
title: Atlassian makes deal with Slack, stock roars to potential record

author: EmilyBary
content:
Shares of Ultra Clean Holdings Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    UCTT, -2.32%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         were down more than 11% in after-hours trading after the semiconductor manufacturing company missed earnings expectations for the second quarter and delivered a weaker-than-expected third-quarter outlook. Net income for the second quarter was $19 million, or 48 cents per diluted share, compared with $20.2 million, or 59 cents per share, a year earlier. Adjusted EPS fell to 55 cents from 62 cents in the year-ago period. Analysts had been expecting 57 cents, according to FactSet. Revenue rose to $290.2 million from $228 million a year earlier and came in roughly in line with projections for $289 million. For the third quarter, the company expects revenue of $200 million to $220 million and adjusted EPS of 28 cents to 38 cents. Analysts surveyed by FactSet were predicting $246 million in revenue and 42 cents in adjusted EPS. Ultra Clean's forecast comes as Lam Research Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    LRCX, -3.46%
also delivered a weaker-than-expected outlook for its September period. Earlier this week, Ultra Clean said it would acquire Quantum Global Technologies LLC.
title: Ultra Clean stock tumbles after earnings, outlook miss expectations

author: ClaudiaAssis
content:
Shares of First Solar Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    FSLR, -3.05%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         fell more than 7% late Thursday after the solar-power company swung to a quarterly loss and revenue fell 50% in the second quarter. First Solar said it lost $49 million, or 46 cents a share, in the quarter, versus earnings of $52 million, or 50 cents a share, a year ago. Sales fell to $309 million from $623 million a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected an adjusted loss of 3 cents a share on sales of $500 million. The company also narrowed the band for its 2018 revenue guidance, to between $2.5 billion and $2.6 billion, from a previous expectation between $2.45 billion and $2.65 billion. Gross margins for the year are expected to come in between 20.5% and 21.5%, from a prior guidance of 21.5% to 22.5%. First Solar shares had ended the regular trading day down 0.7%.
title: First Solar shares retreat 7% after company swings to wider loss

author: EmilyBary
content:
Shares of Juniper Networks Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    JNPR, -0.19%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         were down 6.2% in after-hours trading after the company reported preliminary June-quarter results ahead of expectations but forecast third-quarter earnings below consensus. Preliminary net income was $116.5 million for the quarter, down from $179.8 a year earlier, and equated to 33 cents on a per-share basis. Adjusted earnings per share rose to 48 cents from 28 cents and came in ahead of the FactSet consensus projection of 44 cents. Revenue fell to $1.2 billion from $1.31 billion a year ago. Analysts were expecting $1.18 billion. For the September quarter, Juniper expects to generate $1.14 billion to $1.2 billion, and the company projects adjusted earnings per share of 41 cents to 47 cents. "Our Q3 revenue guidance reflects stronger than expected Q2 business, particularly in Enterprise and the timing of certain cloud and service provider deployments which are taking longer to materialize," the company said in a release. "While customer spending remains dynamic and difficult to predict, we continue to expect a return to year-over-year growth during the fourth quarter." Juniper shares were up 0.7% over the past 12 months, as of Thursday's close, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 15%.
title: Juniper stock falls after third-quarter earnings forecast falls short

author: ClaudiaAssis
content:
Shares of Expedia Group Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    EXPE, -0.64%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         rallied 10% after the company reported second-quarter earnings that surpassed Wall Street expectations. Expedia said it earned $1 million, or a penny a share, in the quarter, compared with $57 million, or 36 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted for one-time items, Expedia earned $1.38 a share in the quarter, compared with 89 cents a year ago. Revenue rose 11% to $2.88 billion, from $2.58 billion a year ago. Excluding Trivago, which Expedia spun off in late 2016, the company posted adjusted earnings of $1.45 a share on sales of $2.71 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected adjusted earnings of 89 cents a share on sales of $2.88 billion. Shares had ended the regular trading day down 1.4%.
title: Expedia shares rally on quarterly earnings beat

author: SueChang
content:
Shares of Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    CMG, -0.45%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         jumped in Thursday's extended session after the gourmet burrito chain posted better-than-expected earnings. Chipotle reported its second-quarter earnings fell to $46.9 million, or $1.68 a share, from $66.7 million, or $2.32 a share, a year earlier. On an adjusted basis, Chipotle would have earned $2.87 a share. However, revenue rose 8.3% to $1.27 billion and comparable restaurant sales grew 3.3%. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast earnings of $2.81 a share on revenue of $1.26 billion. The company raised its 2018 comparable restaurant sales growth outlook to low to mid-single digits from low-single digit previously. Chipotle shares rallied 6.5% after hours.
title: Chipotle shares rally as second-quarter earnings beat expectations

Analysts had been expecting $4.94. Revenue climbed to $3.1 billion from $2.9 billion a year ago and was in-line with analyst expectations. Analysts had been expecting revenue of $2.8 billion and adjusted EPS of $3.89, according to FactSet. author: ClaudiaAssis
content:
Shares of Starbucks Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SBUX, -0.79%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         rose 0.5% late Thursday after the retailer reported fiscal third-quarter results that largely tracked Wall Street estimates. Starbucks said it earned $852.5 million, or 61 cents a share, in the quarter, compared with $691.6 million, or 47 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted for one-time items, the company earned 62 cents a share, compared with 55 cents a share a year ago. Sales rose 11% to $6.31 billion, from $5.66 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected GAAP and adjusted earnings of 61 cents a share on sales of $6.26 billion. Starbucks said its global comparable-store sales increased 1%, the same growth that the analysts surveyed by FactSet expected. Shares ended the regular trading day down 0.3%.
title: Starbucks stock inches higher after company earnings meet expectations

author: MarkDeCambre
content:
U.S. stocks ended Thursday's session mixed, with the Dow closing at its highest level in five months and the broader market weighed by the worst single-session loss of value by a U.S. publicly traded company ever. Shares of Facebook 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    FB, -1.55%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         tumbled nearly 19% on the day. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         finished the session up about 113 points, or 0.4%, at 25,527, marking its third straight gain and its highest close since Feb. 26, according to FactSet data. The S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         meanwhile, ended 0.3% lower at 2,837, pressured by a sinking technology sector 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    XLF, -1.17%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         while the Nasdaq Composite Index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    COMP, -0.67%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         finished the day off 1% at 7,852, a day after posting its 25th record of 2018. The story of the day, however, was Facebook's historic slide as investors responded to disappointing guidance from the social-media giant during its earnings update, pointing to expectations for lower ad revenue in the wake of its Cambridge Analytica scandal. Facebook's decline marked its worst since it became a public company on May 18, 2012 and cut about $120 billion in value from its market capitalization, the steepest loss from a U.S. public company since Intel Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    INTC, -2.57%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shed $90 billion back in 2000, according to WSJ Market Data Group. Because most stock indexes are market-cap weighted, Facebook's powerful drop weighed mightily on the tech-heavy Nasdaq and the broader market, which tends to be market-cap pegged. Optimism for the Dow follows signs of a thaw in trade tensions between the U.S. and its trade partners in Europe.
title: Facebook's historic stock selloff rattles Nasdaq, S&P 500, but Dow ends at 5-month high

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
Amazon.com Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AMZN, -0.64%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares jumped about 4% Thursday afternoon after the company reported its largest quarterly profit total in history, disclosing earnings per share more than double what analysts expected. The e-commerce and cloud-computing company reported second-quarter net income of $2.5 billion, or $5.07 a share, up from earnings of 40 cents a share a year ago and the first time Amazon has reported more than $2 billion in quarterly profit. Amazon reported revenue of $52.9 billion, up from $37.96 billion a year ago but slightly lower than analyst estimates. Analysts on average were expecting earnings of $2.48 a share on sales of $53.37 billion. Amazon shares jumped more than 4% in immediate after-hours trading, following a 3% decline in the regular session to $1,808. The stock has gained 54.6% so far this year, as the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has increased 6.5%.
title: Amazon earnings top $2 billion for record quarter, stock gains

content:
Shares of cybersecurity company Tenable Holdings Inc.

                                         rallied in their first day of trading Thursday. Tenable shares surged nearly 32% to close at $30.25 on volume of more than 9.6 million shares, after the company priced 10.9 million shares at $23 a share late Wednesday. Tenable granted underwriters, which included Morgan Stanley, J.P. Morgan, Allen & Co. and Deutsche Bank, an additional 1.6 million shares to cover over-allotments. The Columbia, Maryland-based company, which filed for its offering as recently as June 29, offers cloud-based vulnerability management service meant to protect assets like network containers and web applications. Tenable follows in the footsteps of other hot cybersecurity stock debuts this year like Carbon Black Inc.
CBLK, -0.41%

ZS, -0.26%

author: SarahToy
content:
Facebook announced on Wednesday a new product called Watch Party, a new way for users to watch videos on the social media platform with each other in real time. The feature is built around Facebook

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    FB, -1.55%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         Groups; a member can click the "Watch Party" icon in the group, select what video or videos they want to watch and the so-called watch party begins. Other members in the group can watch at the same time and chat with each other. "We've been focused on building new ways to bring people together around video, create connections, and ignite conversations; Watch Party is the next step in bringing this vision to life," wrote Erin Connolly, product manager at Facebook, in a company blog post. Facebook shares took a hit this week after the company's earnings report Wednesday showing it had missed expectations on revenue and was seeing slowing user growth, falling nearly 20% on Thursday. The stock has fallen 0.2% so far this year, while the S&P 500

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 6.2%.
title: Facebook has launched 'Watch Party,' a new way to watch videos in real-time with your friends

author: GregRobb
content: The special counsel, Robert Mueller, is examining tweets from President Donald Trump about Attorney General Jeff Sessions and the former FBI director James Comey to see if they played a part in attempts to obstruct the Russia investigation, according to the New York Times on Thursday. The report, which cites three people briefed on the matter, said Mueller wants to question the president about the tweets. Privately, some of Trump's lawyers think Mueller will make a case for interference with the probe by tying together some of the president's actions and tweets, the report said.
title: Mueller examining Trump tweets as part of possible obstruction: NYT

author: WallaceWitkowski
content:
Symantec Inc.'s 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SYMC, -0.26%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         LifeLock identity protection service may have exposed the email addresses of millions of customers, according to a report late Wednesday. Shares of Symantec were up 0.4% at $20.77 on Thursday. Noted cybersecurity blogger Brian Krebs reported late Wednesday that LifeLock just fixed a bug on its site that would allow hackers to fool LifeLock customers in phishing attempts. Krebs said Symantec took the site offline shortly after he contacted the company. A spokesperson for Symantec clarified to MarketWatch that LifeLock's site was not taken offline but a "marketing opt-out page" had been taken down. In late 2016, Symantec said it would buy Lifelock for $2.3 billion, and the deal was closed in February 2017.
title: Millions of LifeLock email addresses may have been exposed: report

The Walt Disney Company will eliminate single-use plastic straws and stirrers at all of its locations by mid-2019, the company announced Thursday. author: EmmaCourt
content:
McKesson Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    MCK, -0.60%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares dropped 3.2% in moderate Thursday morning trade after the drug distributor reported a first-quarter revenue miss. Earnings for the latest quarter came to a loss of $138 million, or a loss of 68 cents per share, after earnings of $309 million, or $1.45 per share in the year-earlier period. The company said it took a pre-tax and after-tax charge of $570 million, or $2.81 per share, related to new United Kingdom government reimbursement reductions announced in late June and changes to McKesson's business structure. Adjusted earning-per-share were $2.90, above the FactSet consensus of $2.89. Revenue rose to $52.61 billion from $51.1 billion, below the FactSet consensus of $52.89 billion. McKesson is "disappointed by the recent government-initiated reimbursement cuts in the U.K. These incremental cuts create ongoing challenges in our U.K. retail pharmacy business," said Chief Executive John Hammergren. McKesson expects 2019 adjusted EPS of $13 to $13.80, compared with the FactSet consensus of $13.42. The company's board of directors also announced on Wednesday a 15% dividend increase to 39 cents per share of common stock, payable on October 1 to shareholders of record as of September 4. McKesson shares have dropped 16.2% over the last three months, compared with a 6.5% rise in the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         and a 5% rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%
title: McKesson shares drop 3% after Q1 revenue miss

author: RobertSchroeder
content: U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer said Thursday he was hopeful about progress toward reaching a new North American Free Trade Agreement. "Hopefully we are in the finishing stages of achieving an agreement in principle that will benefit America's workers, farmers, ranchers and businesses," he told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee hearing.
title: Lighthizer says he's hopeful Nafta agreement in 'finishing stages'

author: TonyaGarcia
content:
Walmart Canada announced plans on Thursday to invest more than $175 million to build a 300,000-square-foot fulfillment center in Surrey, British Columbia. The frozen grocery facility will provide products to 60 stores in British Columbia. It will also create 150-to-200 long-term jobs and 300 jobs for construction and engineering pros. The fulfillment center, which is expected to open in early 2022, will be a zero-waste facility using efficient refrigeration systems and taking other sustainability measures. Walmart Canada operates 410 stores across the country. Walmart Inc.

                                         has gained 2.8% for the period.

author: TonyaGarcia
content:
Consumer electronics retailer RadioShack has announced that it will open more than 100 express locations across the U.S. Founded in 1921, the company filed for bankruptcy in March 2017, two years after a previous bankruptcy filing. More recently, the company has focused on e-commerce and has grown to more than 400 dealer locations. Last week, it announced a partnership with HobbyTown, a hobby and toy retailer, which will bring RadioShack-branded merchandise to 60 HobbyTown franchise locations. The RadioShack Express format will be rolled out in more than 100 HobbyTown locations as a store-in-store.                                          an intimate apparel and swimwear company, saw shares jump 4% in Thursday premarket trading after it gave a business update for its acquisition target, Frederick's of Hollywood. Frederick's has direct-to-consumer e-commerce sales of $20.2 million for the year ending June 30, 2018, up from $16.0 million the year prior. Naked Brand credits the company's upgrade to a mobile platform for the increase. Naked Brand is in the final stages of negotiating the acquisition, and seeks to close the deal in the third-quarter of 2018, according to a statement from Naked Brand Chief Executive Justin Davis-Rice. Frederick's of Hollywood, an intimates brand, was founded in 1946 and is credited with launching the push-up and padded bras in the U.S. Naked Brand seeks to acquire all of Frederick's of Hollywood shares in exchange for forgiveness of debt owed to the wholly-owned subsidiary Bendon Limited. author: AnnekenTappe
content:
The euro 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    EURUSD, -0.2717%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         was slightly weaker against its major rivals early Thursday in New York as the European Central Bank offered an update to its monetary policy. The central bank kept rates unchanged, as expected, emphasizing that it was holding to a plan laid out in June to unwind its asset purchases, but wouldn't move to commence tightening policy until next summer. ECB President Mario Draghi, at an 8:30 a.m. news conference, said the eurozone economy was proceeding on a "solid, broad-based" growth path, but that risks surrounding global themes such as trade remained "prominent". Draghi will be watched closely on forecasts on economic growth in the second half of the year as well as comments on trade and currency strength will be in focus. One euro last bought $1.1727, little changed in negative territory, £0.8894, also little changed from Wednesday but in negative territory, and ¥129.98, down 0.1%, according to FactSet.
title: Euro hovers in negative territory as ECB news conference kicks off

author: SteveGoldstein
content: The U.S. trade deficit in goods widened to $68.3 billion in June, up 5.5% or $3.6 billion, according to the Commerce Department's advanced estimate released Thursday. The report is used by the government in producing the first estimate of GDP, which is released on Friday. Exports fell and imports grew in June. The report also showed flat readings of both wholesale and retail inventories.
title: U.S. trade deficit in goods widens in June as exports fall

author: WilliamL.Watts
content: The European Central Bank on Thursday, as expected, left interest rates unchanged and affirmed its plan to end its monthly bond-buying program in December. The ECB's key lending rate remains at 0%, while the rate paid on deposits parked overnight at the central bank remains at negative 0.4%. The ECB also repeated that it plans to keep rates at present levels "at least through the summer of 2019, and in any case for as long as necessary to ensure the continued sustained convergence of inflation to levels that are below, but close to, 2% over the medium term." As usual, investors will pay close attention to ECB President Mario Draghi's news conference, scheduled to get under way at 2:30 p.m. Frankfurt time, or 8:30 a.m. Eastern.
title: ECB leaves rates unchanged, reiterates plan to end bond purchases in December

Net income declined to $112 million, or 42 cents a share, from $166 million, or 63 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, adjusted earnings per share of 80 cents, below the FactSet consensus of 83 cents. Revenue fell to $2.51 billion from $2.57 billion, topping the FactSet consensus of $2.49 billion. Chief Executive John Visentin, who has been in the role for two months, said the fact that its business model is underpinned by an annuity cash flow makes it challenging to improve revenue and flow cost savings to the bottom line. Vistentin said the company will take action to improve effectiveness and efficiency of its supply chain and go-to-market channels. Separately, Xerox authorized a $1 billion share buyback program, with $500 million of repurchases expected in 2018. The stock, which was still inactive in premarket trade, has tumbled 18.6% over the past three months while the S&P 500

                                    HSY, +0.37%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         reported second-quarter net income of $226.9 million, or $1.08 per share, up from $203.5 million, or 89 cents per share, for the same period last year. Adjusted EPS was $1.14. Revenue totaled $1.75 billion, up from $1.66 billion last year. The FactSet consensus was for earnings of $1.10 per share and revenue of $1.74 billion. Hershey has approved a $500 million stock buyback program, and raised its dividend 10% to $0.722 on the common stock and $0.656 on the Class B common stock. Dividends are payable on September 14, 2018 to shareholders of record as of August 24, 2018. Hershey expects full-year sales to increase on the low end of the 3.5% to 5.5% range. Full-year EPS is expected to be in the range of $4.76 and $4.96, and adjusted EPS is expected to total $5.33 to $5.43. The FactSet consensus is for EPS of $5.32. Hershey shares are down 18.2% for the year to date while the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 6.5% for the period.
title: Hershey earnings and revenue beat expectations, raises dividend

author: TomiKilgore
content:
Shares of Altria Group Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    MO, -0.29%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         slumped 2.4% in premarket trade Thursday, after the tobacco and smokeless products company beat second-quarter earnings expectations but missed on revenue. Net income fell to $1.88 billion, or 99 cents a share, from $1.99 billion, or $1.03 a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, adjusted earnings per share of $1.01 was above the FactSet consensus of $1.00. Revenue fell 5.4% to $6.31 billion, below the FactSet consensus of $6.59 billion, as smokeable revenue declined 6.3% to $5.55 billion and smokeless revenue rose 2.7% to $579 million. Cigarette shipments fell 10.8% to 27.3 million cigarettes, with Marlboro shipments down 10% to 23.5 million. Altria sees 2018 adjusted EPS $3.94 to $4.03, surrounding the FactSet consensus of $3.99. The stock has tumbled 19% year to date through Wednesday while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 6.5%.
title: Altria's stock drops after revenue miss, with cigarette shipments declining 11%

author: EmmaCourt
content:
Raytheon Co. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    RTN, +0.13%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares rose 1.2% in Thursday premarket trade after the company reported second-quarter profit and revenue beats. Earnings for the latest quarter rose to $800 million, or $2.78 per share, from $553 million, or $1.89 per share in the year-earlier period. The FactSet adjusted earnings-per-share consensus was $2.34. Raytheon said that EPS results reflect lower taxes, as a result of the new U.S. tax law, and a pension contribution the company plans to make, which had a favorable tax-related EPS lift of 33 cents. Revenue rose to $6.63 billion from $6.28 billion, compared with the FactSet consensus of $6.51 billion. Raytheon now expects 2018 revenue of $26.7 billion to $27.2 billion, compared with previous guidance of $26.5 billion to $27 billion and the FactSet consensus of $26.7 billion. Raytheon also expects 2018 EPS of $9.77 to $9.97, compared with previous guidance of $9.70 to $9.90 and the FactSet consensus of $9.90. The new guidance reflects the company's pension plan contribution as well as an unfavorable charge due to a a group annuity contract intended to transfer outstanding pension benefit obligations for certain individuals. Raytheon shares have dropped 6.4% over the last three months, compared with a 6.7% rise in the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         and a 4.5% rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%
title: Raytheon shares rise after Q2 profit, revenue beats

ConcoPhillips

"We're benefitting from higher oil prices, but also driving underlying cash flow expansion," Chief Executive Ryan Lance said in a statement. The oil giant is now expecting full-year product of 1,225 to 1.255 MBOED. Shares were slightly lower premarket, but have gained 30.3% in 2018, while the S&P 500

author: TomiKilgore
content:
Share of Allergan PLC 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AGN, -0.03%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         were indicated up nearly 2% in premarket trade Thursday, after the drugmaker beat second-quarter earnings and revenue expectations, and set a new $2 billion stock buyback program. The company reported a net loss that narrowed to $472.5 million, or $1.39 a share, from $795.5 million, or $2.37 a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, such as the impact of amortization and impairments, adjusted earnings per share came to $4.42, above the FactSet consensus of $4.13. Revenue rose to $4.12 billion from $4.01 billion, above the FactSet consensus of $3.92 billion, as 6.5% growth in U.S. specialized therapeutics sales to $1.83 billion beat expectations of $1.62 billion. Allergan raised its 2018 adjusted EPS guidance range to $16.00 to $16.50 from $15.65 to $16.25, which is well above the FactSet consensus of $15.31. Separately, the company said it expects to deploy to new $2 billion share repurchase program, which follows the completion of the $2 billion program announced in September 2017, over the next 12 months. The stock has gained 10% over the past three months through Wednesday, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has tacked on 6.7%.
title: Allergan's stock set to rally after earnings beat and raise, new stock repurchase program

author: MikeMurphy
content: Multiple news sources have reported an explosion outside the U.S. Embassy in Beijing on Thursday. Videos on social media showed emergency officials on the scene and smoke in the area, which also houses a number of other embassies, including India's. There were no immediate details of the cause of the apparent blast, or whether there are casualties. According to reports by Reuters and the Associated Press, Chinese state media said police had stopped a woman who doused herself in gasoline in an apparent self-immolation attempt in front of the embassy shortly before the incident, but that could not be independently verified. The incident happened around 1 p.m. local time. The U.S. Embassy in Beijing is an eight-story facility in a 10-acre compound in the Chaoyang district in the northeastern part of the city.
title: Explosion reported near U.S. Embassy in Beijing

author: EmilyBary
content:
Shares of PayPal Holdings Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    PYPL, -0.18%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         were down 4% in after-hours trading Wednesday, after the company reported revenue and earnings ahead of expectations but forecast third-quarter revenue below the FactSet consensus. PayPal reported net income of $526 million, or 44 cents a share, up from $411 million, or 34 cents a share, a year earlier. The company posted adjusted earnings per share of 58 cents, up from 46 cents in the year-earlier period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had been expecting 57 cents. PayPal has beaten adjusted-earnings estimates in every quarter since its split from eBay Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    EBAY, -0.18%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         in 2015, according to FactSet. Revenue rose to $3.86 billion from $3.2 billion a year ago. The FactSet consensus called for $3.8 billion in revenue. The company reported $139 billion in total payment volume, in line with estimates. PayPal reported 7.7 million net new accounts added. Venmo processed more than $14 billion in volume during the quarter, up 78% from a year ago. For the September quarter, PayPal forecast revenue growth of 12% to 13%. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had been expecting $3.7 billion in revenue, which is 14% above the year-earlier figure. PayPal shares are up 57% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 14%.
title: PayPal stock falls after earnings and revenue beat, Q3 revenue outlook falls short

author: MikeMurphy
content: Eleven conservative Republican House members, led by Rep. Mark Meadows of North Carolina and Jim Jordan of Ohio, introduced a resolution to impeach Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein late Wednesday. The move by the House Freedom Caucus leaders is not seen as a sign that the full House will soon vote to impeach, as it appears to lack support from some Republican leaders. It also comes just a day before the House leaves for a monthlong recess. The impeachment articles accuse Rosenstein, who is overseeing special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian election meddling since Attorney General Jeff Sessions recused himself, of withholding documents, hiding materials and failing to comply with oversight requests.
title: Conservative House members introduce resolution to impeach Rod Rosenstein

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
As Facebook Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    FB, -1.55%
took a jaw-dropping fall in after-hours trading Wednesday following its quarterly earnings report, two competitors came along for part of the ride. Twitter Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    TWTR, +0.16%

                                         both declined in the extended session following Facebook's earnings report, with Twitter falling more than 5% and Snap dropping about 4%. Neither stock was as active as Facebook in the after-hours session, however: While Facebook's off-hours volume hit 28 million about 6:25 p.m. Eastern time, Twitter volume was close to 750,000 and Snap was close to 370,000.
title: Twitter and Snap fall along with Facebook

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
Facebook Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    FB, -1.55%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares plunged even lower Wednesday afternoon, falling more than 17% after the company followed a revenue miss with a weaker-than-expected forecast. Shares were down about 7% before the conference call, when Chief Financial Officer David Wehner disclosed the social-media giant expects a revenue deceleration to continue. "Our total revenue growth rates will continue to decelerate in the second half of 2018, and we expect our revenue growth rates to decline by high single digit percentages from prior quarters sequentially in both Q3 and Q4," he said on the conference call. Wehner also said Facebook still expects expenses to grow 50% to 60% from last year.
title: Facebook stock plummets farther after forecast

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
Qualcomm Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    QCOM, -0.40%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         said in a post-earnings conference call Wednesday that Apple Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AAPL, -0.30%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         would rely solely on a competitor's modem chips in its next iPhone, almost assuredly referring to Intel Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    INTC, -2.57%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         Apple had been splitting iPhone modem duties between Qualcomm and Intel, which did not offer CDMA connections in its wireless modems. Previous reports have said that if Intel adds CDMA, as it has, it could win all the share in future iPhones, and Qualcomm seemed to confirm that Wednesday. "We believe Apple intends to solely use our competitors' modems rather than our modems in its next iPhone release," Qualcomm Chief Financial Officer George Davis said while discussing the company's fourth-quarter forecast. "We will continue to provide modems for Apple legacy devices." The announcement didn't immediately hurt Qualcomm stock, which was up more than 7% after announcing an earnings beat and plans to drop acquisition plans for NXP Semiconductors NV. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NXPI, -1.17%
title: Qualcomm suggests Apple will use Intel modems in new iPhone

author: ClaudiaAssis
content:
Shares of Biogen Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    BIIB, -1.12%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         fell more than 9% late Wednesday after the drug maker, alongside Eisai Co. Ltd. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    ESALY, -1.53%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shared data about an experimental drug trial to combat Alzheimer's disease. The drug slowed the worsening of Alzheimer's, with the highest treatment dose biweekly demonstrating "a statistically significant" slowing of clinical decline of 30% compared to a placebo at 18 months, the companies said. The companies had said earlier in July the drug showed positive results but had offered few details. Shares of Biogen ended the regular trading session up 3%, with Wall Street closely following the release of the study as the drug could position Biogen as a leader in drugs to fight the memory-destroying disease.
title: Biogen shares down 9% after Alzheimer's trial results

author: EmilyBary
content:
Shares of Equifax Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    EFX, -0.03%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         were down 2.1% in after-hours trading Wednesday after the credit-reporting agency posted better than expected second-quarter earnings but delivered an outlook for the third quarter that missed analyst expectations. The company reported net income of $144.8 million, or $1.19 a share, down from $165.4 million, or $1.36 a share, a year earlier. Adjusted earnings fell to $1.56 a share, from $1.60 a share in the year-earlier quarter, but topped the FactSet consensus estimate of $1.54. The company delivered revenue of $877 million for the quarter, up from $857 a year earlier. Analysts had been expecting $886 million. Equifax forecast third-quarter revenue of $853 million to $863 million. The FactSet consensus figure for third-quarter revenue is for $870 million. Shares were down 12% over the past 12 months, as of Wednesday's close, compared with a 14% rise for the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%
title: Equifax stock falls after Q3 outlook falls short, earnings beat

author: SueChang
content:
Shares of Mondelez International Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    MDLZ, -0.52%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         gained in Wednesday's extended session after the food giant posted better than expected quarterly earnings and raised its dividend. Mondelez reported its second-quarter earnings fell to $323 million, or 22 cents a share, from $498 million, or 32 cents a share a year earlier. On an adjusted basis, the maker of Oreo cookies and Cadbury chocolates would have earned 56 cents a share. Revenue edged up to $6.11 billion from $6 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast earnings of 54 cents a share on revenue of $6.13 billion. Mondelez also hiked its dividend by 18% to 26 cents a share and said it expects 2018 organic net revenue to grow in the high end of a 1% to 2% range as well as a double-digit increase for adjusted earnings. Shares rose 3% after hours.
title: Mondelez shares climb on better-than-expected earnings, dividend hike

author: ClaudiaAssis
content:
Citrix Systems Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    CTXS, +0.23%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares rose 3.9% late Wednesday after the technology company beat Wall Street earnings expectations for the second quarter. Citrix said it earned $107 million, or 73 cents a share, compared with $109 million, or 70 cents a share, in the second quarter of 2017. Adjusted for one-time items, Citrix earned $178 million, or $1.28 a share, compared with $158 million, or $1.03 a share, in the year-ago period. Sales rose 7% to $742 million, from $693 million a year ago, the company said. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected adjusted earnings of $1.20 a share on sales of $716 million. Citrix said it expects revenue between $2.92 billion to $2.95 billion in 2018, and adjusted EPS between $5.30 to $5.40 for the year. Shares ended the regular trading day 1.5% higher.
title: Citrix shares rise 4% on quarterly earnings beat

author: EmilyBary
content:
Shares of Xilinx Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    XLNX, -3.09%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         were up 9.8% in after-hours trading Wednesday after the company reported better-than-expected quarterly results and issued an outlook for the current quarter that exceeded analyst projections. The supplier of programmable logic devices reported fiscal first-quarter net income of $190 million, up from $157 million a year earlier. On a per-share basis, the company posted earnings of 74 cents, up from 59 cents a year ago. Analysts had been expecting 71 cents in GAAP EPS, according to FactSet. Revenue for Xilinx rose to $684 million in the quarter, up from $603 million in the year-earlier period. Analysts had been projecting revenue of $674 million. The company forecast revenue of $700 million to $720 million for the fiscal second quarter, whereas analysts had been expecting $680 million. Shares were up 0.8% so far this year, as of Wednesday's close, compared with a 6.5% rise for the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
Sarepta Therapeutics Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SRPT, -2.58%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares fell in after-hours trading Wednesday, when the company announced a study of a potential drug for Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy had been halted by the Food and Drug Administration. The study of a potential gene-therapy approach to the disease "has been placed on clinical hold due to the presence of a trace amount of DNA fragment in research-grade third-party supplied plasmid," the company noted. Sarepta said it still plans to begin dosing patients in the study by the end of the year as long as the FDA accepts its plans to address the issue. Sarepta planned to hold a conference call at 5 p.m. Eastern time to address the issue. Sarepta shares initially fell more than 9% after the news was released, but declines soon settled to about 5.5%.
title: Sarepta stock drops after Muscular Dystrophy study halted by FDA

author: ClaudiaAssis
content:
Shares of Ford Motor Co. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    F, -1.72%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         fell more than 3% late Wednesday after the auto maker missed quarterly expectations and lowered its profit guidance for the year, saying it was "a particularly challenging quarter for Asia Pacific and Europe," and vowed to focus on China and take "urgent action to address underperformance." Ford earned $1.1 billion, or 27 cents a share, compared with $2.05 billion, or 51 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Sales fell $1 billion to $38.9 billion in the quarter. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected GAAP and adjusted earnings of 31 cents a share on sales of $39.2 billion for the quarter. Results in North America were "solid," with sales of F-Series pickup trucks on track for a record through the first six months of the year, Ford said. That performance was offset by "unexpected challenges with our overseas operations and headwinds in the business environment," Chief Executive Jim Hackett said in a statement. "Despite this, our fitness actions continue to take hold and we're clearly committed to redesigning and restructuring the underperforming parts of our business," he said. Ford is making the "hard decisions" it needs on certain items, and will sell what it can't turn around, the company said. It lowered the range for full-year 2018 adjusted earnings to $1.30-$1.50 a share. The analysts surveyed by FactSet expect adjusted EPS of $1.51 for the year.
title: Ford shares down after earnings miss, lowered profit guidance

author: WallaceWitkowski
content:
Mohawk Industries Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    MHK, -1.07%
