Mohawk shares fell 14% after hours. The company reported second-quarter net income of $196.6 million, or $2.62 a share, compared with $260.7 million, or $3.51 a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings were $3.51 a share. Revenue rose to $2.58 billion from $2.45 billion in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated $3.90 a share on revenue of $2.58 billion. For the third quarter, Mohawk estimates earnings of $3.54 to $3.64 a share , while analysts expect earnings of $4.29 a share.
title: Mohawk shares fall on earnings, outlook miss

author: RobertSchroeder
content:
President Donald Trump said he and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker agreed to work toward "zero tariffs" and "zero subsidies on non-auto industrial goods." At an unscheduled news conference following a joint meeting, Trump also said the EU would buy more U.S. soybeans almost immediately and that he and Juncker would work to resolve tariffs on European steel and aluminum. U.S. stocks 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         jumped on reports that the U.S. and EU had reached a deal to resolve trade tensions. Trump has threatened to impose tariffs on European autos but said he'll hold off on any retaliation as long as talks are taking place.
title: Trump and Juncker agree not to impose any new tariffs, to eliminate steel and aluminum levies

author: EmilyBary
content:
Visa Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    V, -0.20%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares were down 1.1% in after-hours trading Wednesday after the card giant reported lower-than-expected volume growth but better-than-anticipated earnings and revenue. The company posted net income of $2.3 billion, or $1 a share, up from $2.1 billion, or 86 cents, a year earlier. Adjusted earnings rose to $1.20 a share from 86 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Analysts tracked by FactSet expected adjusted EPS of $1.09. Visa reported revenue of $5.2 billion, compared with $4.6 billion a year ago. The FactSet consensus called for revenue of $5.1 billion. Payments volume rose 11%, while analysts had been expecting 12.4% growth. The company reaffirmed its prior full-year outlook of low double-digit nominal revenue growth. Visa expects roughly 1 percentage point of positive foreign-currency impact. Visa shares have gained 42% over the past 12 months, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         of which Visa is a component, has gained 17%.
title: Visa stock falls after volume miss, earnings beat

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
Qualcomm Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    QCOM, -0.40%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares received a jolt Wednesday afternoon after the chip maker beat quarterly earnings expectations, confirmed that it plans to end a long-planned acquisition of NXP Semiconductors NV 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NXPI, -1.17%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         and buy back up to $30 billion in stock. NXP shares gained more than 5% in immediate after-hours trading after gaining 1% in regular trading, when reports suggested the company would dump the NXP deal and instead buy back shares. "We intend to terminate our purchase agreement to acquire NXP when the agreement expires at the end of the day today, pending any new material developments," Chief Executive Steve Mollenkopf said in Wednesday's announcement. "In addition, as previously indicated, upon termination of the agreement, we intend to pursue a stock repurchase program of up to $30 billion to deliver significant value to our stockholders." Qualcomm reported third-quarter net income of $1.2 billion, or 82 cents a share, on sales of $5.6 billion, up from $5.37 billion a year ago. After adjusting for stock-based compensation and other effects, the company claimed earnings of $1.01 a share, up from 83 cents a share a year ago. Analysts on average expected Qualcomm to report adjusted profit of 71 cents a share on sales of $5.19 billion, according to FactSet, after the chip maker predicted adjusted earnings of 65 cents to 75 cents a share on revenue of $4.8 billion to $5.6 billion. Qualcomm predicted fourth-quarter adjusted earnings of 75 cents to 85 cents a share on sales of $5.1 billion to $5.9 billion. For the company's fourth quarter, analysts on average were predicting adjusted profit of 77 cents a share on sales of $5.47 billion, according to FactSet. Qualcomm stock has fallen 7.2% so far this year, as the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 5.5%.
title: Qualcomm plan to kill NXP deal, earnings beat send stock popping higher

author: WallaceWitkowski
content:
Qualcomm Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    QCOM, -0.40%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         is throwing in the towel on its bid to acquire NXP Semiconductors NV 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NXPI, -1.17%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         following resistance from Chinese regulators and plans to propose a stock buyback plan instead, according to a report Wednesday. Shares of NXP fell 2.6% to $98.01, while Qualcomm shares declined 0.1% to $58.80. The companies had set a deadline of July 25 for Chinese regulators to greenlight the deal after a few dozen extensions. Qualcomm plans to add $10 billion to its stock buyback program and tell investors it is abandoning its pursuit of NXP during its earnings announcement after the close, according to CNBC, citing sources close to the matter. The development is a far cry from March when Intel Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    INTC, -2.57%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         was reportedly considering buying Broadcom Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AVGO, -2.01%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         if it acquired Qualcomm, which was still gunning for NXP.
title: Qualcomm plans huge stock buyback after ditching NXP bid: report

author: MarkDeCambre
content:
The broad-market S&P 500 index is trading at its highest point since its late-January peak, underscoring a resurgence for stocks following a fall into correction territory in early February. The S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         most recently was up 0.5% at 2,834. The index hasn't traded above this level since Jan. 29, when it closed at 2,853.53, according to FactSet data. A further close above 2,839.10 would mark the index's emergence from correction territory, defined as a drop of at least 10% from a recent peak. The S&P 500 fell into correction territory on Feb. 8, hitting a low of 2,581 and if it closes 10% above that level, most market technicians view such a climb as characterizing an official end of an asset's corrective phase. The Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         remains several percentage points from emerging out of correction territory, while the Nasdaq Composite Index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    COMP, -0.67%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has notched at least three records so far in July. Wednesday's advance came amid some optimism from talks between President Donald Trump and European Union official Jean-Claude Juncker, which could result in easing trade tensions between the U.S. and the eurozone. Trade tensions have been a main source of anxiety for market participants for weeks.
title: S&P 500's midday jump takes it near highest level since stocks tumbled into correction 6 months ago

author: RobertSchroeder
content: A second meeting between President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin will be delayed until "after the first of the year," Trump national-security adviser John Bolton said in a statement Wednesday. Trump believes it should take place "after the Russia witch hunt is over," Bolton said, using a term Trump regularly employs to describe special counsel Robert Mueller's probe into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election. It is not exactly known, however, when Mueller's investigation will conclude.
title: White House says Trump's next Putin meeting won't happen till 2019

author: WilliamL.Watts
content:
Oil futures ended solidly higher Wednesday after data showed a larger-than-expected fall in domestic inventories last week. West Texas Intermediate crude for September delivery 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    CLU8, -0.18%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         on the New York Mercantile Exchange rose 78 cents to close at $69.30 a barrel, a gain of 1.1%. The Energy Information Administration said oil stocks fell by 6.1 million barrels in the week ended July 20. Analysts surveyed by The Wall Street Journal had forecast a fall of 2.9 million barrels, while the American Petroleum Institute late Tuesday had reported an inventory decline of 4.2 million barrels.
title: Oil futures end higher after drop in U.S. crude inventories

author: CiaraLinnane
content:
Shares of Acorda Therapeutics Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    ACOR, +0.56%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         tumbled more than 17% Wednesday, after the company said an appeals court has denied its motion on patents for its multiple sclerosis treatment Ampyra. The company had filed for an injunction pending a decision in its appeal of a U.S. District Court decision from 20717 in patent litigation with generic drug makers. That court upheld a patent that is set to expire on July 30, 2018, but invalidated four others that would have allowed it to retain exclusivity until 2027. "If the Court of Appeals does not overturn the District Court's decision by July 30, 2018, multiple generic drug manufacturers may decide to launch at-risk generic versions of Ampyra," the company said in a regulatory filing. Ampyra chalked up net sales of $103 million in the first quarter and the company backed 2018 guidance of $330-$350 million. In 2017, the drug accounted for more than half of all sales. Shares have gained 11.2% in 2018, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 5.9%.
title: Acorda Therapeutics denied motion in patent case, stock slides 17%

author: MarkDeCambre
content:
Gold futures settled modestly higher Wednesday, ending a two-session slide as the dollar edged lower. August gold 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    GCQ8, -0.59%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         closed $6.30, or 0.5%, higher at $1,231.80 an ounce. There were few catalysts to sway the metal but traders keyed in on weakness in the popular ICE U.S. Dollar Index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DXY, +1.36%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         a gauge of the buck against six rival currencies, as a catalyst to purchase beleaguered gold, which has hovered around a year low. Greenback's gauge was trading down about 0.1% at 94.466, in late Wednesday afternoon trade. A weaker dollar can make commodities priced in the unit more attractive to buyers using other currencies. Overall, gold has been in a decided downtrend of late, with Wednesday's action offering a slight glimmer of hope, coming also as assets perceived as risky, like U.S. stocks, were mostly trading higher. The S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         was up 0.2%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    COMP, -0.67%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         climbed 0.5%. Only the Dow Jones Industrial Average lagged behind its equity-benchmark peers, off 0.2%, weighed by a decline in Boeing Co. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    BA, -1.25%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         fresh off its quarterly results. A percolating trade spat between the U.S. and Europe has been in focus on the day, with a key test under way in the form of a meeting between European Union's top official and President Donald Trump, in an attempt to alleviate tariff tensions that could prove disruptive to global markets and economies.
title: Gold halts 2-session skid to settle modestly higher as dollar slips

author: CiaraLinnane
content:
Whirlpool Corp. stock 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    WHR, -2.66%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         was downgraded to sector perform from outperform by analysts at RBC on Wednesday, on concerns about the pace of market share loss in North America and Europe among other factors. Whirlpool reported second-quarter earnings on Tuesday, and said it lost about 400 basis points of market share in the period to competitors. "Our concern is that a return to sustained growth for WHR may require sacrificing price/margin absent a change in competitive dynamics," analysts led by Mike Dahl wrote in a note. "This balance may become more difficult in '19 as competitor capacity ramps." In Europe, the appliance maker is also aiming to recoup lost market share, but is also facing stiff competition and a slow growth environment, said the note. Meanwhile, raw material inflation and high freight costs are also weighing. Shares were down 4.4% and have lost 26.9% in 2018, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 5.7%.
title: Whirlpool downgraded to sector perform vs. outperform at RBC

author: RobertSchroeder
content: A federal judge has rejected an effort by President Donald Trump to stop a lawsuit alleging he violates the Constitution by doing business with foreign governments, the Washington Post reported Wednesday. Maryland and Washington, D.C., are suing the president for what they say is violating the emoluments clause, which bars federal officials from taking payments from foreign states. The suit is focused on money spent by foreign governments at Trump's D.C. hotel.
title: Judge rejects Trump effort to stop lawsuit over business with foreign governments: report

author: EmmaCourt
content:
Biogen Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    BIIB, -1.12%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares rose more than 4% in extremely heavy Wednesday morning trade in advance of a major Alzheimer's disease drug presentation planned for the afternoon. The Wednesday event, detailing phase 2 trial results for the Alzheimer's disease therapy BAN2401, could position Biogen as a leader in the difficult-to-treat disease, with two promising Alzheimer's disease therapies. The release has also become the subject of Wall Street buzz because many of Biogen's other important clinical trials, including for its other Alzheimer's disease therapy, aducanumab, won't put out new results for another year or so. Biogen and partner Eisai [s:jp:4523] have already said that the phase 2 trial had positive results. But depending on whether the full data are better or worse than expected, the stock could either move up $40 or down $20, Leerink analyst Geoffrey Porges said. Biogen shares also rose 4.1% in Tuesday trade after the company reported second-quarter profit and revenue beats and upbeat 2018 guidance. Biogen shares have surged 41% over the last three months, compared with a 6.9% rise in the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         and a 4.4% rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%
title: Biogen shares rise 4% before release of Alzheimer's disease trial results

Analysts surveyed by The Wall Street Journal had produced a consensus forecast for a fall of 2.9 million barrels, while the American Petroleum Institute, an industry group, on Wednesday had reported a 4.2 million barrel decline. author: RobertSchroeder
content: President Donald Trump's former attorney Michael Cohen planned to use a Delaware shell company he created in September 2016 to buy the rights to a former Playboy model's story about having an affair with Trump, The Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday. The report says Cohen created a firm called Resolution Consultants LLC to buy the rights to Karen McDougal's story, which had been bought earlier by the publisher of the National Enquirer. Trump has denied having sex with McDougal. Cohen referred to his plan to create a company to buy her story in a recording aired by CNN Tuesday.
title: Ex-Trump lawyer Cohen formed shell company to buy model's story: WSJ

According to the Times report, Facebook's approval initially appeared on a government database, but it's since been withdrawn. The Times cites a person familiar with the matter and said that Facebook planned to set up an innovation hub in China. The core Facebook service has been blocked in China for more than 10 years. Facebook shares are up 31% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500

author: EmmaCourt
content:
HCA Healthcare Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    HCA, -0.02%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares surged nearly 7% in Wednesday morning trade after the company reported second-quarter profit and revenue beats and upbeat 2018 guidance. Earnings for the latest quarter rose to $820 million, or $2.31 per share, from $657 million, or $1.75 per share in the year-earlier period. The company said that second-quarter results included 2 cents per share on facilities sales and a tax benefit of 34 cents per share connected to the new U.S. tax law. The FactSet adjusted earnings-per-share consensus was $2.16. Revenue rose to $11.53 billion from $1.073 billion, compared with the FactSet consensus of $11.34 billion. The company now expects 2018 revenue of $45.5 billion to $46.5 billion, compared with previous guidance of $45 billion to $46 billion. The FactSet 2018 revenue consensus was $45.82 billion. HCA Healthcare also now expects 2018 EPS of $9 per share to $9.40 per share, up from a previous guidance range of $8.50 to $9 and the FactSet consensus of $9.38. HCA Healthcare shares have surged 17.5% over the last three months, compared with a 6.9% rise in the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         and a 4.6% rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%
title: HCA Healthcare shares rise nearly 7% after Q2 beats

                                         shares are up 12% in Wednesday trading after the food ordering and delivery service reported second-quarter earnings that beat expectations and announced an acquisition. Net income totaled $30.1 million, or 33 cents per share, up from $14.7 million, or 17 cents per share, for the same period last year. Adjusted EPS was 50 cents. Revenue totaled $239.7 million, up from $158.8 million last year. The FactSet consensus was for earnings of 42 cents per share and revenue of $233.0 million. Gross food sales grew to $1.2 billion from $880 million last year. And active diners grew to 15.6 million from 9.2 million last year. GrubHub also announced the acquisition of LevelUp, a mobile payment solution for national and regional restaurant brands, for $390.0 million in cash. GrubHub expects third-quarter revenue of $232 million to $240 million. The FactSet consensus is for $230.6 million. And full-year revenue is expected to be $966 to $983 million, ahead of the $960.6 million FactSet consensus. GrubHub shares are up nearly 52% for the year so far while the S&P 500 index

                                         has gained 5.5% for the period.

The meeting could provide insight into the state of one of the biggest forces that has driven equity prices this year. author: SarahToy
content:
MoviePass parent Helios and Matheson Analytics Inc. implemented a 1-to-250 reverse stock split Tuesday at market close, which substantially boosted the company's share price in premarket trade on Wednesday, though shares sold off in premarket trade. Shareholders traded in 250 Helios and Matheson

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    HMNY, -19.87%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares for one share, effectively multiplying the stock price by 250. The stock's close Tuesday was adjusted to $21.25 from 8.5 cents, but were down 25% ahead of the open, which would imply a pre-split adjusted price of just above 6 cents. Analysts see the split as the company's way to bolster its shares to prevent the company from being delisted, as a stock is in danger of being delisted if it trades below $1 for 30 consecutive days, according to Nasdaq rules. The company has had its share of troubles recently: It has burned through its cash holdings and disclosed earlier this year that an auditor had expressed "substantial doubt" about the company's ability to continue. The company's stock has fallen 98.6% so far this year, while the S&P 500

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 5.5%.
title: MoviePass parent Helios and Matheson implements 1-to-250 reverse stock split, boosting share price

author: TomiKilgore
content:
Shares of resTORbio Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    TORC, -0.09%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         nearly tripled in premarket trade Wednesday, after the biopharmaceutical company announced positive results from its dose-ranging phase 2b trial of its treatment for respiratory tract infections (RTIs). The company said RTB101 demonstrated a statistically significant and clinically meaningful reduction in the percentage of patients with one or more RTIs during the treatment period, the primary endpoint of the study with the 10 mg once-daily dose, while RTB101 10 mg in combination with everolimus 0.1 mg didn't meet the primary endpoint. "This Phase 2b has successfully defined a dose, RTB101 10 mg once daily, to be evaluated in future pivotal studies," said Chief Medical Officer Joan Mannick. The stock, which went public in January, rocketed 169% ahead of the open, to trade about 60% above the initial public offering price of $15. The rally came at a good time, as the lock-up expires Wednesday, meaning insiders looking to sell shares can now do so in the open market. The stock had tumbled 47% from the closing price on the first day of trading through Tuesday, while the iShares Nasdaq Biotechnology ETF

                                         is little changed during the time and the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has slipped 1.8%.
title: ResTORbio's stocks rockets on positive trial results, just as post-IPO lock up expires

author: EmilyBary
content:
Shares of NXP Semiconductor Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NXPI, -1.17%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         are down 3.8% in premarket trading Wednesday, as the deadline for Qualcomm Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    QCOM, -0.40%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         to obtain Chinese regulatory approval for its planned acquisition of NXPI looms at the end of the day. The companies said in April that they would end the deal if they didn't win China's approval by the end of the day on July 25. The deal is thought to be caught up in trade-war tensions between the U.S. and China. Reuters reported Wednesday that one source said Qualcomm was hitting a "stone wall" as it tried to negotiate with China's regulators, while another said that deal approval on Wednesday looks unlikely. Shares of Qualcomm, which would have to pay a $2 billion break-up fee if the deal doesn't happen, are down 0.4% premarket.
title: NXPI stock falls as Qualcomm approval deadline looms at day-end

author: TomiKilgore
content:
Shares of Freeport-McMoRan Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    FCX, -1.31%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         jumped 2.5% in premarket trade Wednesday, after the mining company reported a second-quarter profit and revenue that topped expectations. Net income rose to $869 million, or 59 cents a share, from $268 million, or 18 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, adjusted earnings per share came to 58 cents, above the FactSet consensus of 52 cents. Revenue increased to $5.17 billion from $3.71 billion, beating the FactSet consensus of $4.97 billion. Average realized price for copper rose to $3.08 per pound from $2.65, and for gold inched up to $1,274 per ounce from $1,243. Consolidated sales of copper totaled 989 million pounds, up from 942 million pounds a year ago and above the guidance provided in April of 970 million pounds. "Despite the recent decline in copper prices associated with the uncertain impact on the global economy of recent international trade actions, we remain positive on the outlook for copper prices given limitations on supply and the important role of copper in the global economy," said Chief Executive Richard Adkerson. The stock had dropped 15.2% year to date through Tuesday, while high-grade copper futures

                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         had gained 5.5%.
title: Freeport-McMoRan's stock jumps after earnings and revenue rose above expectations

author: TomiKilgore
content:
Shares of Boeing Co. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    BA, -1.25%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         slumped 2.7% in premarket trade Wednesday, after the aerospace and defense giant beat second-quarter profit and revenue expectations, although its largest business segment--commercial airplanes--came up a bit short on sales. Net earnings rose to $2.20 billion, or $3.73 a share, from $1.75 billion, or $2.87 a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, core earnings per share came to $3.33, above the FactSet consensus of $3.25. Revenue grew 5% to $24.26 billion, topping the FactSet consensus of $24.04 billion. Commercial airplanes revenue increased 1% to $14.48 billion, missing the FactSet consensus of $14.86 billion, while Boeing's second-largest business segment by sales, defense, space and security, saw revenue rise 9% to $5.59 billion to beat expectations of $5.40 billion. Looking ahead, Boeing raised its 2018 revenue guidance range to $97 billion to $99 billion--the FactSet consensus of $98 billion--from $96 billion to $98 billion, and affirmed its core EPS outlook of $14.30 to $14.50, which is below the FactSet consensus of $14.53. The stock has soared 21.5% year to date through Tuesday, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%

author: CiaraLinnane
content: Aquestive Therapeutics priced its initial public offering at $15 a share, according to Nasdaq, the midpoint of its price range of $14 to $16. The company, which focuses on developing treatments for diseases affecting the central nervous system, sold 4.5 million shares to raise $68 million. Shares will start trading on Nasdaq later Wednesday under the ticker symbol "AQST."
title: Aquestive Therapeutics prices upsized IPO at $15, midpoint of $14 to $16 range

                                         shares plunged 7.3% in Wednesday premarket trading after the company reported second-quarter revenue that missed expectations and gave weak third-quarter guidance. Net income totaled $63.8 million, or $1.26 per share, compared with a loss of $17.7 million, or 35 cents per share, for the same period last year. Adjusted EPS was $1.17. Revenue totaled $535.4 million, down from $572.9 million. The FactSet consensus was for EPS of $1.12 and revenue of $549.0 million. The company saw sales growth in China, Mexico and South Africa while Brazil, India and Indonesia experienced "significant decreases. Tupperware says emerging markets account for 71% of sales. "The company classifies established market units as those operating in Western Europe, including Scandinavia, the United States, Canada, Australia and Japan and its remaining units as emerging market units," Tupperware explained. Tupperware expects to incur an additional $6 million in pretax costs for the remainder of 2018 for its previously-announced revitalization program. Tupperware expects third-quarter EPS of 74 cents to 79 cents, and adjusted EPS of 80 cents to 85 cents. The FactSet consensus is 97 cents.                                          are down 1% in premarket trading after Pivotal Research Group analyst Jeffrey Wlodarczak downgraded the stock to hold from buy, keeping his $200 price target intact. He views consensus expectations for Spotify's premium monthly-active-user additions to be overly aggressive. He lowered his second-quarter estimates to 5.5 million net new monthly active users, below consensus figures of 7 million. He also reduced his full-year numbers. "The decision to reduce our subscriber forecasts was primarily based on what we view as credible weakening global Google Spotify search trends data that continued into 3Q," Wlodarczak wrote. "Our subscriber forecast would have been reduced further, but we forecast management will raise second-half marketing spend to offset these trends." Spotify shares are up 11.6% over the past three months, while the S&P 500

content:
United Parcel Service Inc.

                                         shares declined 1.3% in premarket trade on Wednesday after the company reported second-quarter financial results. Though UPS reported profit and revenue beats, sales for its U.S. domestic unit -- its largest unit by revenue -- missed the consensus. Earnings for the latest quarter rose to $1.49 billion, or $1.71 per share, from $1.38 billion, or $1.58 per share in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings-per-share were $1.94, above the FactSet consensus of $1.93. Adjusted EPS results excluded an after-tax charge of 23 cents per share largely related to a voluntary early retirement program that is part of the company's cost-cutting plan. Revenue rose to $17.46 billion from $15.93 billion, above the FactSet consensus of $17.33 billion. Of the company's business segments, U.S. domestic sales missed the FactSet consensus, while revenue for the international segment and the supply chain and freight segment beat the consensus. UPS said that in the U.S. domestic segment, higher base-rates and fuel surcharges offset headwinds from customer and product mix. UPS still expects 2018 adjusted EPS of $7.03 to $7.37, compared with the FactSet consensus of $7.25. UPS shares have lifted 3.5% over the last three months, compared with a 6.9% rise in the S&P 500

content:
Teradyne Inc.

                                         shares shot up more than 8% in the extended session Tuesday, after the company beat on the top and bottom line. The industrial automation supplier reported second-quarter net income of $101 million, or 52 cents a share, compared with $175 million, or 87 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted for amortization of acquired assets, among other things, earnings were 59 cents a share. Revenue fell to $526.9 million from $696.9 million in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated adjusted earnings of 49 cents a share on revenue of $507 million. For the third quarter, analysts model adjusted earnings of 52 cents a share on revenue of $518 million. The company said it expects adjusted third-quarter earnings of 59 cents to 66 cents a share on sales of $540 million to $570 million. The stock has fallen 3.6% this year, with the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         rising 5%. Teradyne shares closed down 0.9% to $43.62 during regular trading.

The American Petroleum Institute reported Tuesday that U.S. crude supplies slid by 3.16 million barrels for the week ended July 20, according to sources. The API data also showed supplies of gasoline fell by 4.87 barrels, while distillate stockpiles slid 1.32 million barrels. Supply data from the Energy Information Administration will be released Wednesday. Ultra Clean Holdings Inc.

Under the agreement, Ultra Clean will pay about $342 million in cash for Quantum Global. In 2017, QGT generated revenue of $217.9 million and net income of $22 million. Ultra Clean expects the deal to close in the third quarter, while adding to its net income in the fourth quarter.

author: ClaudiaAssis
content:
Shares of AT&T Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    T, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         fell 1% late Tuesday after the company reported second-quarter results that beat Wall Street expectations, raised its profit guidance for 2018, but saw sales fall year-on-year. AT&T said it earned $5.1 billion, or 81 cents a share, in the quarter, compared with $3.9 billion, or 63 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Adjusted for one-time items, the company earned 91 cents a share, compared with 79 cents a share a year ago. Sales fell to $39 billion, from $39.8 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet expected adjusted earnings of 87 cents a share on sales of $38.6 billion. The company also raised its adjusted EPS guidance for the year to the "high end of $3.50 range," it said. The analysts surveyed by FactSet expect 2018 adjusted EPS of $3.39. The quarterly results included 16 days of Time Warner results, as the acquisition was completed June 14, the company said. "Time Warner joins us coming off an impressive second quarter. Turner turned in solid subscription and advertising revenue growth, Warner Bros. is in high gear with a record number of series in production, and HBO delivered strong subscriber revenue growth," AT&T said. "Our goal is to reshape the way media and entertainment work for consumers, and you will see us continue to do exactly that." AT&T ended the regular trading day up 2.2%.
title: AT&T shares fall 1% after earnings beat, increased guidance

author: WallaceWitkowski
content:
Texas Instruments Inc.

                                         shares ticked higher in the extended session Tuesday after the chipmaker's quarterly results, while topping Wall Street estimates, came as no surprise having been telegraphed last week along with the chief executive's departure announcement. Texas Instruments shares rose 0.2% after hours, following a 0.8% decline to close regular trading at $113.80. The company reported second-quarter net income of $1.41 billion, or $1.40 a share, compared with $1.06 billion, or $1.03 a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $4.02 billion from $3.69 billion in the year-ago period. Prior to last week's preliminary results, analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated earnings of $1.30 a share on revenue of $3.96 billion. Last week, Texas Instruments provided a preview of results as it announced the departure of President and CEO Brian Crutcher after six weeks on the job. The company sees third quarter earnings of $1.41 and $1.63 a share on revenue of $4.11 billion to $4.45 billion. Analysts expect $1.49 a share on revenue of $4.27 billion.
title: Texas Instruments stock ticks higher on earnings report

Previously, the company had provided guidance of $2.15 to $2.40 a share on sales of $1.05 billion to $1.08 billion. iRobot stock clocked huge gains last year, but has fallen back in 2018, declining 7.2% so far this year as the S&P 500 index

                                         will be implementing a 1-for-250 reverse stock split at market close on Tuesday, the company announced. "We believe this is an important step that will facilitate our access to capital over the next several years and enable us to implement our growth plans for MoviePass, MoviePass Films and MoviePass Ventures," said Ted Farnsworth, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of HMNY. Analysts see the split as a way to bolster the company's shares, which are currently trading at 9 cents. If a stock trades below $1 for 30 consecutive days, it is in danger of being delisted, according to Nasdaq rules. The company has burned through its cash holdings, disclosing in an April filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that its average cash deficit was $21.7 million a month from September 2017 to April 2018. Helios also disclosed that an auditor had expressed "substantial doubt" about the company's ability to continue as a going concern. The company's stock has fallen 98.5% so far this year, while the S&P 500

                                         bonds were slightly higher Tuesday, a day after a sharp selloff triggered by concerns raised by a report that suggested the company was trying to wring concessions from suppliers. The 5.300% notes that mature in August of 2025 were trading at 89.50 cents on the dollar to yield 7.225%, or at a yield spread of 427 basis points over Treasurys. The notes fell more than 2 points at their worst levels on Monday. The Wall Street Journal said that Tesla had asked some suppliers to rebate payments going back to 2016, but Tesla said that it asked fewer than 10 suppliers for reductions in total capital expenditure spending on projects that began in 2016 but are still not complete. The company is focused on reaching a "more sustainable" long-term cost basis with suppliers, including pushing for future cost reductions, a spokesman told MarketWatch in emailed comments. The news sent the stock down about 5% in early trade. Shares were last down 2% and have fallen 4.5% in 2018, while the S&P 500

author: SteveGoldstein
content: Billy McFarland, the founder of the failed venture Fyre Festival that sought to host a "once-in-a-lifetime" music festival in the Bahamas, has admitted the Securities and Exchange Commission allegations against him, agreed to a permanent officer-and-director bar, and agreed to disgorgement of $27.4 million. That is deemed satisfied by the forfeiture order entered in McFarland's sentencing in a related criminal case. The chief marketing officer, Grant Margolin, and independent contractor, Daniel Simon, agreed to the settlement without admitting or denying the charges, as did the Fyre Media Inc. and Magnises Inc. Margolin has agreed to a 7-year director-and-officer bar and must pay a $35,000 penalty, and Simon has agreed to a 3-year director-and-officer bar and must pay over $15,000 in disgorgement and penalty.
title: Failed Fyre Festival founder reaches deal with SEC

content:
Goldman Sachs analysts downgraded Illinois Tool Works Inc.

                                         stock to neutral from buy and removed it from its Americas Conviction List, after the company's second-quarter earnings fell short of expectations. "The bottom line is that after two disappointing quarters, we have less conviction that ITW can deliver differentiated margin/EPS growth over the next 12 months," analysts led by Joe Ritchie wrote in a note. Goldman was buy-rated on the stock based on strong execution and a differentiated margin story, which it expected would lead to beats on earnings estimates. The company has outperformed margin expectations for at least the last five years, as it streamlined its portfolio. "After two quarters of missed expectations, our conviction has waned," said the note. "Specifically, we under-appreciated the margin headwinds associated with price/cost. Additionally, the company called out growth investments (60bps) for the first time, highlighting that margins could remain pressured for the near-to-medium term." Illinois Tool Works shares were up 2.2% on Tuesday, but are down 16.5% in 2018, while the S&P 500

                                         has gained 5.5%.
title: Goldman downgrades Illinois Tool Works after earnings that fell short

author: JeffryBartash
content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) - The manufacturing and service sides of the U.S. economy showed steady and rapid growth in July, according to a preliminary or "flash" reading by IHS Markit . The manufacturing index rose a tick to 55.5 from 55.4. The services index slipped to 56.2 from 56.5. Readings over 50 indicate growth . The latest report indicates the economy continued to expand in midsummer at a healthy pace despite heightened tensions over trade. The biggest worry for companies are rising prices. IHS Markit said the increase in what companies charge rose at the fastest clip since the firm first began to collect information in the fall of 2009.
title: U.S. economy growing steadily in July, Markit PMIs show

The approval will bring to market the first oral treatment for moderate to severe pain from endometriosis in more than a decade. author: SarahToy
content:
Netflix is developing its first European production hub in Madrid, the company announced Tuesday. The production facility will be located at Ciudad de la Tele, a sprawling 22,000-square-meter campus in Tres Cantos, and will be central growing Netflix's

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NFLX, -1.00%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         slate of Spanish-language original content. With over 13,000 cast, crew and extras working on 20 Netflix original productions across Spain this year, the hub's development is a reflection of Netflix's deepening investment in Spain. "The establishment of our first European production hub will create new opportunities for Spain's incredible creative talent, as well as demonstrating our commitment to the production of original content throughout Europe," said Erik Barmack, vice president of international originals at Netflix, in a statement. The company has several Spanish titles in production, such as "Elisa & Marcela" and "The Alcásser Murders," and will soon release season 3 of "Las Chicas del Cable" and young adult drama "Élite." Netflix shares tumbled last week after it announced it had missed subscriber and revenue expectations in the second quarter, though most analysts remain optimistic about the company and see the drop as a buying opportunity. The company's shares have shot up 89% so far this year, while the S&P 500

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has risen 5%.
title: Netflix announces first European production hub in Madrid

content:

"We and a growing group of investors have come to believe a nearer-term combination of SiriusXM

"We believe Liberty President and CEO, Greg Maffei, has long desired to combine Sirius and Live Nation into a single music distribution company and has encouraged a marriage of his two music industry interests in the past." Ross said that Sirius now appears to have a "terminal value problem" as the company doesn't have many logical places to employ its free cash flow. He wrote that Live Nation, which owns TicketMaster and operates concert venues, "is near maximum leverage" and could benefit from Sirius' balance sheet. Synovus shares sank 6.6%. The deal, which is expected to clsoe by the first quarter of 2019, is valued at $2.9 billion in total. Under terms of the deal, FCB shareholders will receive 1.055 Synovus shares for each FCB share they owned. Based on Monday's closing price for Synovus's stock, that values FCB shares at $58.15 each, or 1.8% below Monday's closing price of $59.20. Synovus said with the addition of FCB, Synovus will become a "top five regional bank by deposits in the Southeast region." FCB's stock had run up 16.5% year to date through Monday, while Synovus shares had rallied 15.0% and the S&P 500

The FactSet adjusted EPS consensus was $2.58. Revenue rose to $8.39 billion from $7.81 billion, above the FactSet consensus of $8.38 billion. 3M raised its 2018 EPS guidance from $8.68 to $9.03 to $9.08 to $9.38, to reflect the impact of its communication markets business divestiture and other actions. The new 2018 EPS guidance comes in above the FactSet consensus of $8.78. The company also now expects adjusted 2018 EPS of $10.20 to $10.45, compared with the FactSet consensus of $10.34 and previous guidance of $10.20 to $10.55. 3M shares have slumped 1.1% over the last three months, compared with a 6.5% rise in the S&P 500

                                         shares fell 2.6% in Tuesday premarket trading after the consumer products company reported second-quarter revenue that missed expectations and issued a profit warning. Kimberly-Clark brands include Kleenex, Huggies diapers, and Cottonelle. Net income totaled $455.0 million, or $1.30 per share, down from $531.0 million, or $1.49 per share, for the same period last year. Adjusted EPS was $1.59. Sales totaled $4.60 billion, edging up from $4.58 billion last year. The FactSet consensus was for EPS of $1.57 and sales of $4.62 billion. The results "reflect a challenging environment, particularly with commodity inflation," said Chief Executive Thomas Falk in a statement. Higher commodity costs were also the reason the company lowered its earnings guidance. Kimberly-Clark now expects EPS of $6.60 to $6.80 versus prior guidance for $6.90 to $7.20. The company expects net sales to be breakeven to up 1% versus the prior assumption for an increase of 2% to 3%. Kimberly-Clark shares have sunk 12.6% for 2018 so far while the S&P 500 index

author: EmmaCourt
content:
Celgene Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    CELG, -0.77%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares rose 1.6% in Tuesday premarket trade after the company reported positive results from a phase 3 cancer trial after-hours the previous day. The trial evaluated Celgene's chemotherapy drug Revlimid along with the cancer drug rituximab in patients with relapsed/refractory indolent lymphoma, finding that the two drugs led to a highly statistically significant improvement in the trial's primary endpoint, progression-free survival, as compared with rituximab plus the placebo. Celgene also said that a "favorable trend" was seen when it came to overall survival, though "follow-up will continue for the mature [overall survival] results." The company will submit data from the trial at a future medical meeting, and plans to prepare global regulatory submissions in the first quarter of next year. Many of Celgene's largest drugs are expected to lose patent protection, but Celgene has struggled to get other products approved. "Celgene's stock has been plagued by the triple threats of poor investment decisions, weak operational performance and long term patent uncertainty, and as a result has been one of the worst performing stocks in the large cap biotech group over the last 3, 6, and 12 months," said Leerink analyst Geoffrey Porges. "Something had to go right... Despite recent history, not everything in the company's portfolio will fail, nor every operational result disappoint." Celgene shares have dropped 4.6% over the last three months and 18.5% year-to-date. The S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has lifted 6.5% over the last three months, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has risen 4.3%.
title: Celgene shares lift on positive results for cancer drug trial

Food and facilities service group Aramark

                                         said Tuesday that it will "significantly reduce" the use of disposable, single-use plastics like straws, stirrers and bags by 2022. The company will take action in 19 countries where two billion meals are served across schools, workplaces, hospitals and other venues each year. Efforts include phasing out straws and stirrers in favor of eco-friendly alternatives starting in September 2018 and expanding offerings of reusable water bottles, coffee mugs, and take-out containers. Goals include 100% elimination at national parks, select business dining locations and university residential dining, and 30% to 60% reduction at grade schools, sports venues and health care facilities. Aramark joins companies like McDonald's Corp.

H, -1.28%

author: AnnekenTappe
content:
The Turkish lira 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    USDTRY, +5.8094%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         dropped against the U.S. dollar on Tuesday, after the Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey kept its interest rates unchanged. The CBRT's benchmark one-week repo rate currently stands at 17.75%. Tuesday's monetary policy decision was considered a litmus test to determine how much influence newly re-elected President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has over his central bank. With double-digit inflation and an ailing currency, market participants had hoped for a rate hike, but Erdogan is vehemently against higher rates. One dollar last bought 4.8982 lira, up 3.3%, according to FactSet.
title: Turkish lira drops versus dollar as central bank holds rates unchanged

The carrier is now expecting capacity to rise 7.5% to 9.5% in the third quarter and to increase 6.5% to 7.5% in the full year. RASM is expected to be flat to up 3% for the third quarter. content:
Harley-Davidson Inc.

                                         said Tuesday it had net income of $242.3 million, or $1.45 a share, in the second quarter, down from $258.9 million, or $1.48 a share, in the year-earlier period. Excluding manufacturing optimization costs, EPS came to $1.52, the company said. Revenue fell to $1.525 billion from $1.577 billion. The FactSet consensus was for EPS of $1.41 and revenue of $1.424 billion. International retail motorcycle sales rose 0.7% in the quarter, while U.S. retail sales fell 6.4%. Worldwide retail sales fell 3.6%. The company said it will push ahead with plans to build the next generation of riders globally, investing in opportunities that inspire ridership sooner and deliver growth for the future. "We will motivate our existing loyal riders and inspire future riders who are not even thinking about two-wheeled freedom," Chief Executive Matt Levatich said in a statement. The company is still expecting full-year motorcycle shipments of 231,000 to 236,000. It expects motorcycles segment margins to be about 9% to 10%, given the expected impact of tariffs. author: WallaceWitkowski
content:
Infinera Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    INFN, +0.47%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares ticked higher in the extended session following an after-hours halt Monday after the optical transmission equipment maker said it plans to acquire privately held network services company Coriant. Infinera shares rose 0.7% after hours, following a 1.5% decline to close the regular session at $8.84. Under the deal, Infinera said it will pay $150 million in cash for Coriant at closing, with additional amounts of about $25 million in the two quarters after the close and $55 million "over a period of years," and issue about 21 million shares, for a total of about $430 million in cash and stock. The company has about 151 million shares outstanding. Infinera expects the deal to close in the third quarter. The company said it expects second-quarter revenue "slightly higher than the midpoint of our previously reported guidance range." Infinera had forecast revenue of $203 million to $213 million, while analysts are looking for $208.6 million.
title: Infinera shares tick higher on announcement of Coriant acquisition

Fannie Mae 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    FNMA, -0.63%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         said late Monday that its chief executive, Timothy Mayopoulos, will step down at the end of the year as well as other management changes. Also, effective Aug. 6, David Benson will become president, reporting to the CEO, and Celeste Brown will become chief financial officer. Fannie's board said it will start a search for Mayopoulos's replacement.
title: Fannie Mae's CEO to leave by year end, other exec changes announced

author: ClaudiaAssis
content:
Shares of Whirlpool Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    WHR, -2.66%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         plunged more than 8% late Monday after the appliance maker swung to a surprise quarterly loss, posted sales that missed Wall Street expectations, and said it expects lower global revenue growth for the year thanks in part to poor performance in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. Whirlpool said it lost $657 million, or $9.50 a share, in the quarter, versus earnings of $189 million, or $2.52 a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted for one-time items, Whirlpool earned $3.20 a share, compared with $3.35 a share a year ago. Sales fell to $5.1 billion, from $5.3 billion a year ago. Analysts expected adjusted earnings of $3.43 a share on sales of $5.3 billion. Whirlpool said it expects GAAP per-share earnings between 15 cents and 75 cents in 2018 and adjusted 2018 per-share earnings between $14.20 and $14.80 a share "as favorable product price/mix and share repurchases are expected to be more than offset by lower global revenue growth, increased expectations for global cost inflation, and weaker than expected performance in the EMEA region," it said in a statement. The analysts surveyed by FactSet expect per-share adjusted earnings of $15.64 for the year. As a result of below-expectations performance in EMEA, "we are taking strong actions to improve our operational execution, and remain confident that we will deliver value for our shareholders in the coming quarters," Chief Executive Marc Bitzer said in a statement. Shares of Whirlpool ended the regular trading day down 0.7%.
title: Whirlpool shares tank on surprise quarterly loss, lower sales

author: SueChang
content:
Vitamin Shoppe Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    VSI, +8.22%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         rallied in Monday's extended session after the nutiritional supplement retailer named Sharon Leite as chief executive officer, effective Aug. 27. Leite served as president at Godiva Chocolatier and Sally Beauty prior to joining Vitamin Shoppe. Shares jumped 4.6% after hours.
title: Shares of Vitamin Shoppe rally as company names new CEO

author: WallaceWitkowski
content:
Penn Virginia Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    PVAC, +1.12%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares were halted in the extended session Monday just before the oil and gas company said it was evaluating strategic initiatives. Shares of Penn Virginia closed down 0.6% at $84.84 in Monday's regular session. In a statement, the company said those initiatives could include "a corporate sale, merger or other business combination, one or more strategic acquisitions, or other transactions." No timetable has been set and the company hired Jefferies LLC as its advisor in the matter.
title: Penn Virginia shares halted for 'strategic initiatives' announcement

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
Alphabet Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    GOOGL, -0.95%
GOOG, -0.92%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares roared to prices that would be record highs if they occurred in regular trading, after reporting second-quarter earnings Monday afternoon that were slammed by a recent record antitrust fine out of Europe yet easily surpassed expectations. The Google parent company reported $3.2 billion in net income for the quarter, which works out to $4.54 a share, down from $5.01 a share a year ago, when the company also dealt with a big antitrust fine out of the EU. Without the fine, Alphabet would have reported earnings of $11.75 a share, the company said, well higher than analysts' average estimate of $9.64 a share, according to FactSet. Alphabet reported revenue after accounting for traffic-acquisition costs of $26.24 billion, up from $20.91 billion in the second quarter of 2017 and higher than the average analyst estimate of $25.58 billion. Alphabet shares jumped nearly 5% in after-hours trading Monday to prices higher than its intraday record of $1,221.59, following a 1.1% gain in regular trading to $1,211. The company's class A shares have gained 15% so far this year, as the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has increased 4.8%.
title: Alphabet stock rises to potential record after earnings smash expectations
