                                         has gained 3.8%.

author: GregRobb
content: The Justice Department informed Congress in March that it is reinvestigating the 1955 slaying of Emmett Till due to "new information," according to a report from the Associated Press. The black teenager was abducted from the home in Mississippi where he was staying. Till's mutilated body was discovered weighed down in a river. Two white men were charged with murder but were later acquitted. A book published in 2017 said a key figure in the case acknowledged lying about the events, the AP report said. Pictures of Till's battered body helped galvanize the civil rights movement.
title: Justice Department says it is reinvestigating slaying of Emmett Till, whose death spurred civil rights movement: AP

                                         rallied 2% in premarket trade Thursday, bouncing from a 6% slide suffered over the previous three sessions amid concerns over how the clearing out of millions of fake accounts would affect user numbers. Analyst Rob Sanderson at MKM Partners reiterated his buy rating on the social media company, saying, "Getting rid of bad actors and rampant bot use on the network is a good thing." And the fact that the crack down on fake accounts suggests Twitter is getting better at artificial intelligence, which Sanderson stressed "is important" for the stock's long-term outlook. "Deep learning expertise has become a primary engineering focus for [Twitter] especially over the past 2 years," Sanderson wrote. "This is helping police the network, but could also have game-changing potential in solving user experience challenges." The stock has run up 51% over the past three months, while the S&P 500

                                         has tacked on 4.1%.

author: CiaraLinnane
content:
Zogenix Inc. shares 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    ZGNX, +0.10%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         soared about 19% in premarket trade Thursday, after the biotech reported positive results in a late-stage trial of a treatment for the severe form of epilepsy, Dravet syndrome, in children and young adults. The company said the Phase 3 study of its investigational drug ZX008 met its primary endpoint of reducing convulsive seizure frequency, as well as secondary endpoints. "These impressive study results show the significant impact the addition of ZX008 made in reducing the burden of convulsive seizures for patients who are not adequately controlled using stiripentol, the standard of care for the treatment of Dravet syndrome in Europe," said Professor Rima Nabbout, M.D., Ph.D., Department of Pediatric Neurology, Reference Center for Rare Epilepsies, Necker Enfants Malades Hospital, and Principal Investigator of the trial, called Study 1504. If approved, the drug has the potential to be transformative, for a disease with few available treatment options, he added. Zogenix shares have gained 16.6% in 2018 through Wednesday, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 3.8%.
title: Zogenix shares soar 19% premarket after news of positive trial for severe epilepsy treatment

Rio Tinto's U.S.-listed shares rose 1.2% in premarket trade and Freeport's stock rallied 1.8%. Freeport currently owns 90.6% of the Grasberg mine and Inalum owns the rest. Rio Tinto currently has the right to 40% of production above an agreed level and 40% of all production after 2022. In 2017, the mine produced 468 kilotons of copper and Rio Tinto's share was 5.7 kilotons. Separately, Freeport and Inalum have entered into an agreement in which Inalum will buy an additional stake in the Grasberg mine. Rio Tinto's stock has edged up 0.9% year to date through Wednesday and Freeport shares have shed 8.4%, while the S&P 500

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
Broadcom Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AVGO, -2.01%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         announced late Wednesday afternoon that it has agreed to acquire CA Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    CA, +0.05%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         for $44.50 a share, confirming earlier reports. Broadcom said the price represents an equity value of $18.9 billion and an enterprise value of $18.4 billion for the software company. "This transaction represents an important building block as we create one of the world's leading infrastructure technology companies," Broadcom Chief Executive Hock Tan said in Wednesday's announcement. "With its sizeable installed base of customers, CA is uniquely positioned across the growing and fragmented infrastructure software market, and its mainframe and enterprise software franchises will add to our portfolio of mission critical technology businesses." Broadcom said the deal would be immediately accretive to its non-GAAP EPS and help drive long-term adjusted margins higher than 55%. Broadcom is funding the deal with $18 billion in debt financing and cash on hand, and expects the deal to close in the fourth quarter. Broadcom shares dropped 5.9% in late trading Wednesday, after closing with a 2.8% decline; CA shares jumped 16.2%.
title: Broadcom confirms $18.9 billion acquisition of CA Inc.

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
Farmland Partners Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    FPI, +3.12%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         responded to accusations Wednesday afternoon from a short seller that sent shares to all-time lows in the regular trading session, saying the "allegations are false." Farmland Partners stock bounced back with an 8% gain in after-hours trading, after falling 39% in the regular session. An admitted short seller posted an article on Seeking Alpha that claimed Farmland Partners was giving loans to related tenants that created a risk of insolvency for the company, but Farmland Partners said that the loans in question were about 1% of its revenue and proclaimed "None of the borrowers under the program as of March 31, 2018 were related parties, or have other business relationships with the Company, other than as borrowers and, in some cases, tenants." "It is horrifying the amount of damage that this self-interested, anonymous party's false allegations caused today to the company's stockholders," Chief Executive Paul Pittman said in the announcement. "We are evaluating what avenues are available to the company and its stockholders to remedy the damage inflicted."
title: Farmland Partners denies short seller's accusations

author: SueChang
content:
Trade talks between the U.S. and China have recently halted after three rounds of negotiations amid mounting tensions between the two largest economies in the world, Bloomberg reported Wednesday, citing five people familiar with the situation. Officials from the U.S., led by Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, have met with a Chinese team led by Vice Premier Liu He since May without any significant progress, the news agency said. For the moment, there are no plans to resume talks to break the impasse, setting the stage for a drawn out battle between the two economic giants. Stocks fell on Wednesday after the Trump administration announced plans to levy more tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese products with the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         down 0.6% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.8% to 24,725.
title: High-level trade talks between U.S. and China break down: report

author: WallaceWitkowski
content:
Salesforce.com Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    CRM, -0.21%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares rallied to an all-time high Wednesday and were on track for their highest close ever following a round of price target hikes from analysts. Shares of Salesforce hit an intraday high of $145.64, and were last up 2.2% at $145.57, which would be a new closing record for the stock. Shares have been on a tear lately and are on track for their fifth up session in a row for a total streak gain of 5.3%. On Tuesday, Oppenheimer analyst Brian Schwartz hiked his price target on Salesforce to $160 from $152, adding to a series of July price target hikes. In July, four other analysts have raised their price targets on the stock. Of the 43 analysts who cover Salesforce, 38 have overweight or buy ratings and five have hold ratings, with an average target price of $150.69, according to FactSet. Salesforce shares are up 42% for the year, compared with a 3.8% gain in the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                                    COMP, -0.67%
title: Salesforce stock hits records after analyst price target hikes

author: MyraP.Saefong
content:
U.S. oil prices dropped back toward $70 a barrel on Wednesday, losing 5% to finish at their lowest in over two weeks. The Energy Information Administration reported that U.S. crude supplies sank 12.6 million barrels last week. The news, however, failed to offset pressure from expectations that Libya will soon resume oil exports and concerns surrounding the economic impact of worsening U.S.-China trade tensions and a stronger dollar. August West Texas Intermediate crude 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    clq8

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         dropped $3.73, or 5%, to settle at $70.38 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the lowest finish since June 25, according to FactSet data.
title: U.S. oil prices lose 5%, drop back toward $70 a barrel

author: MaxA.Cherney
content:
Walt Disney Co. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DIS, -1.30%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         and Activision Blizzard Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    ATVI, +0.16%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         have inked a deal that will bring the popular team shooter Overwatch League to several of Disney's channels, such as ESPN and ABC, the companies said Wednesday. Activision stock is up 1.6% to $77.41 and Disney stock is up 1.1% to $107.21 in early afternoon trading. The deal is another reminder of the rising popularity of pro videogame viewing, an industry that analysts expect to be worth hundreds of millions this year and billions in the future. The playoff games will begin Wednesday at 8 p.m. Eastern Time on Disney XD, and ESPN3; the finals will air on ESPN later in July. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but ESPN said in a blog post that it was a multiyear contract and amounts to "hundreds of hours of live and highlight programming" across ESPN, ESPN2, Disney XD, ABC and various streaming services. Overwatch League debuted in January with 12 teams representing cities such as Boston, New York Shanghai and Seoul, though the teams will all compete at an arena in Burbank, Calif. Disney stock is flat this year, as Activision has gained 22%. The S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 4.5% this year.
title: Disney to air Blizzard's Overwatch League eports championships in prime time

author: CiaraLinnane
content:
Twitter Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    TWTR, +0.16%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         said Wednesday it is removing 'locked' accounts from its platform as part of a broader effort to build trust with users. In a blog post, Vijaya Gadde, legal, policy and trust and safety lead, said the company regularly reaches out to account owners when it detects sudden changes in behavior. The company then locks the account if the owner fails to validate it and change their password. Most of the activity will take place in the next few days and is likely to mean a change of four followers or fewer for most account holders. "Follower counts are a visible feature, and we want everyone to have confidence that the numbers are meaningful and accurate," said Gadde. The move is not expected to affect Twitter's monthly active user or daily active user metrics, two key measurements of the business. Shares were up 0.5% on Wednesday, and have gained 83.2% in 2018, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 3.8%.
title: Twitter is removing 'locked accounts but says it won't hurt key metrics

author: CiaraLinnane
content:
The Tesla employee who has been engaged in a corporate legal dispute with Chief Executive Elon Musk has formally filed a whistleblower tip with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Washington Post reported Wednesday, citing his attorney. Martin Tripp, who Musk fired last month and then sued for allegedly hacking the company's computer systems, leaking information to the press and stealing secrets, has told the SEC that TEsla had pushed for potentially damaging measures in order to meet production goals, including allegedly placing batteries with puncture holes into vehicles and reusing scrapped parts, the paper reported. Tripp also claimed that Tesla inflated weekly numbers by up to 44%. Tesla did not return a request for comment made by the newspaper. Tesla shares were down 1.1% Wednesday, but are up 2.6% in 2018, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 3.8%.
title: Tesla employee fired and sued by Elon Musk takes dispute to SEC: report

author: SteveGoldstein
content: President Donald Trump told NATO leaders that they should double their defense spending from the current target by 2024 of 2% of GDP to 4%, according to a Bloomberg News story quoting Bulgaria's president. "President Trump, who spoke, raised the question not just to reach 2%, today, but set a new target - 4%. He just left after he announced that," Bulgarian president Rumen Radev told reporters, according to BNR public radio, as quoted by Bloomberg. Many countries, notably Germany, are struggling to reach 2%.
title: Trump reportedly told NATO leaders to boost defense spending to 4% of GDP

author: MyraP.Saefong
content:
U.S. oil prices pared much of their earlier losses Wednesday after the Energy Information Administration reported that domestic crude supplies plunged by 12.6 million barrels for the week ended July 6. Analysts surveyed by S&P Global Platts had forecast a fall of 4.8 million barrels, while the American Petroleum Institute on Tuesday reported a drop of 6.8 million barrels, according to sources. Gasoline stockpiles fell by 700,000 barrels for the week, but distillate stockpiles jumped 4.1 million barrels higher for the week, according to the EIA. The S&P Global Platts survey forecast a supply decrease of 1 million barrels for gasoline and a rise of 1.7 million barrels for distillate stocks. August crude

                                         fell 40 cents, or 0.5%, to $73.71 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, up from $73.27 before the supply data.
title: U.S. oil prices pare losses after EIA reports a weekly plunge in U.S. crude supplies

author: MarkDeCambre
content:
Canada's loonie was showing its strength against the U.S. dollar Wednesday morning after the country's central bank lifted key interest rates, as had been widely expected. Bank of Canada hiked interest rates to 1.5% from 1.25%. One U.S. dollar last bought C$1.3087 of the Canadian currency 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    USDCAD, +0.1370%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         on Wednesday, down 0.2% from C$1.3114 late Tuesday in New York. The interest-rate increase comes as the U.S.'s northern ally has been contending with trade-related worries, including negotiations over the North American Free Trade Agreement--also including Mexico-- which have been on pause for weeks as President Donald Trump adopts an increasingly protectionist posture against the rest of the world.
title: Canada's loonie climbs against the buck as BOC hikes benchmark rates

author: JeffryBartash
content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) - Wholesale inventories in the U.S. jumped 0.6% in May as companies boosted production to meet growing demand for their wares. Sales shot up 2.5% in the month. The ratio of inventories to sales, meanwhile, fell to 1.24 from 1.27. That's how many months it would take to sell all the inventory on hand. One year ago, the inventory-to-sales ratio was higher at 1.31. An increase in inventories adds to gross domestic product.
title: Wholesale inventories in U.S. climb 0.6% in May

author: GregRobb
content: Chicago Fed President Charles Evans, who had been skeptical of the need for higher interest rates, on Wednesday said he now supported more tightening this year. "The economy seems so strong it seems natural that businesses and consumers can live with" slightly higher rates, Evans said, in an interview with the Wall Street Journal. He said whether the Fed raised rates one or two more times this year was not very important in the overall picture. Evans had been in the dovish camp at the Fed, worried about persistent low inflation. In the interview, Evans said inflation now "looks quite good" after its recent rebound.
title: Fed's Evans, once a skeptic, now backs more interest-rate hikes: WSJ

author: TomiKilgore
content: IKEA said Wednesday it is recalling Lurvig water dispensers for pets, citing a "suffocation hazard." The Sweden-based home furnishings retailer said the water dispensers were sold in U.S. stores and online between October 2017 and June 2018 for $7.99 each. The company said it had received two reports worldwide that pets had suffocated after getting their heads stuck in the water dispenser. "IKEA urges customers to stop using the water dispenser and return it to any IKEA store for a full refund," the company said in a statement on its website.
title: IKEA recalls Lurvig water dispensers for pets because of 'suffocation' hazard

author: JeffryBartash
content: The wholesale cost of goods and services rose in June at the highest yearly rate in almost seven years, reflecting broad inflationary pressures in a fast-growing U.S. economy. The producer price index rose 0.3% June, the Labor Department said Wednesday. That's a tick above the MarketWatch forecast. The 12-month rate of wholesale inflation, meanwhile, climbed to 3.4% from 3.1%, marking the highest perch since the waning months of 2011. The core rate rose 0.3% in June. It was up 2.7% in the past year.
title: Wholesale inflation hits highest level since 2011, PPI shows

author: TomiKilgore
content:

                                         dropped 2.3% in premarket trade Wednesday, after the air carrier cut its second-quarter outlook for unit revenue growth, citing lower-than-anticipated domestic yields. The company now expects total revenue per available seat mile (TRASM) to increase 1.0% to 3.0% from a year ago, compared with previous guidance of 1.5%-to-3.5% growth. The company also lowered its outlook for second-quarter capacity to 72.9 billion available seat miles from 73.1 billion, while increasing its estimate for the average per-gallon fuel price to $2.24 to $2.29 from $2.18 to $2.23. The company's outlook for cargo revenue rose to about $260 million from $250 million, and for other revenue to $695 million from $670 million. Separately, the company said it expects the IT issue that resulted in one of its regional carriers, PSA Airlines, to cancel about 3,000 flights in June to reduce pre-tax income by about $35 million. The stock has tumbled 25% year to date through Tuesday, while the NYSE Arca Airline Index

title: American Airlines stock drops after TRASM outlook cut

That acceleration is notable given that bitcoin

As such, he concluded that Square is not a bitcoin play and contrasted the app's continued momentum with a decline in Coinbase app downloads. Dolev's $82 price target makes him the most bullish analyst on the stock who's tracked by FactSet. Square shares are down 0.6% in premarket trading but up 155% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500

                                         disclosed Wednesday that it will terminate its pension plan, effective Sept. 28. The labeling and packaging materials company said there will be no change in benefits for the approximately 11,200 current participants. The pension plan is currently underfunded by about $240 million, and Avery Dennison expects to contribute $200 million in cash, funded by commercial paper borrowings, before Aug. 15. The company said it expects to record non-cash charges of between $575 million to $600 million as a result of the termination plan, with about $100 million recognized in the fourth quarter of 2018. The plan is expected to settle long-term liabilities currently estimated at $950 million, through a combination of voluntary lump-sum payments to eligible participants in 2018 and the purchase of a group annuity contract with one or more insurance companies in the first half of 2019. Avery Dennison's stock, which is still inactive in premarket trade, has dropped 10.6% year to date, while the S&P 500

author: RachelKoningBeals
content: President Donald Trump took aim at ally Germany in particular in his first public comments at an opening breakfast at NATO's annual summit Wednesday. "Germany, as far as I'm concerned, is captive of Russia because it is getting so much of its energy from Russia," Trump said, referencing Germany's gas deal. Trump again all-but ordered members of the alliance to increase their defense spending "immediately." Trump had signaled ahead of the trip that his mission was to secure greater spending into NATO from other members, but critics were skeptical of the tough-talk approach, with some relations already strained by recent trade moves. Trump is set to meet with both German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron on Wednesday. He meets with Russian President Vladimir Putin on July 16.
title: Trump opens NATO summit by saying Germany is a 'captive' of Russia

author: MikeMurphy
content: The head of Uber Technologies Inc.'s human resources department resigned Tuesday following allegations that she dismissed racial discrimination complaints at the company, Reuters reported. Chief Executive Dara Khosrowshahi announced the resignation of Chief People Officer Liane Hornsey in an email seen by Reuters. Hornsey, who was one of Uber's leading voices on workplace diversity and discrimination, was reportedly under investigation for systematically dismissing internal racial-bias complaints. Uber has faced a number of complaints and lawsuits alleging sexual and racial discrimination and harassment, including a female software engineer who sued in May. In March, Uber agreed to settle a class-action discrimination lawsuit by 420 female and minority employees for $10 million. Khosrowshahi, who took over as CEO from founder Travis Kalanick last year, has pledged to clean up Uber's corporate culture.
title: Uber HR executive resigns amid allegations she dismissed racial-bias complaints: report

author: MikeMurphy
content: Federal authorities will release hundreds of detained migrant families, who will be given ankle-bracelet tracking monitors, according to a New York Times report late Tuesday. That would effectively mean a return to the "catch and release" border policy that President Donald Trump had vowed to stop. The move comes after court rulings requiring children separated from their parents to be reunited, and preventing families from being held for more than 20 days. The Trump administration's "zero-tolerance" policy is still in effect, the Times said, and all adults found crossing the border illegally will be prosecuted, though not necessarily detained. An ICE official told the Times that migrant families would be given ankle bracelets "and released into the community." Earlier Tuesday, a federal judge ordered the government to reunite detained families quicker. Only 38 of 102 children under 5 years old had been reunited with their parents by Tuesday's court-ordered deadline.
title: Detained migrant families to be released, given ankle monitors: report

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
President Donald Trump claimed Tuesday evening that Pfizer Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    PFE, -0.17%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         had promised to roll back drug-price increases that he had targeted earlier this week, sending Pfizer stock down. "Pfizer is rolling back price hikes, so American patients don't pay more," Trump said in a tweet that mentioned a meeting with Pfizer Chief Executive Ian Read and Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar. "We applaud Pfizer for this decision and hope other companies do the same." Trump publicly railed against Pfizer and other drug manufacturers who were reportedly planning to increase costs on certain drugs on Monday. Pfizer confirmed the tweet in a statement later Tuesday, saying it would defer price increases that went into effect on July 1 "to give the president an opportunity to work on his blueprint to strengthen the healthcare system and provide more access for patients." Pfizer said it would hold off on increases until Trump's plan takes effect or the end of the year, whichever comes first. Pfizer stock fell about 0.9% in after-hours trading following Trump's tweet Tuesday, after posting daily gains in the regular sessions on Monday and Tuesday following the president's original tweets. Pfizer stock has gained 3.3% so far this year as the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has increased 4.5%.
title: Pfizer stock dips as Trump says Pfizer CEO agreed to drop drug price hikes

content:

                                         could be slapped with a 500,000-pound fine, or about $660,000, by a U.K. regulator over improperly handled data from 87 million users, the company confirmed late Tuesday. The British Information Commissioners Office, which enforces data-protection laws, filed its initial results of the investigation into the Cambridge Analytica scandal, and accused the tech titan of failing to prevent user data ending up in Cambridge's hands. Facebook can respond to the ICO findings prior to the independent agency reaching its final decision about whether to levy the fine. The fine represents the profits from roughly 13 minutes of Facebook operations, according to MarketWatch calculations. Facebook stock was down 1% in after-hours trading and closed down 0.6% to $203.54 during the regular session. "As we have said before, we should have done more to investigate claims about Cambridge Analytica and take action in 2015," Facebook chief privacy officer Erin Egan said in a statement, adding that the company would "respond soon." Facebook stock is up 15% this year, as the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 4.5%.
title: Facebook may be fined by U.K. over Cambridge Analytica scandal

Supply data from the Energy Information Administration will be released Wednesday. Analysts polled by S&P Global Platts expect the EIA to report a fall of 4.8 million barrels in crude supplies. They also forecast a supply decrease of 1 million barrels for gasoline, and an increase of 1.7 million barrels for distillates. The Wall Street Journal reported about a half-hour before the close Tuesday that the European Commission expects to levy a large fine against Google for abusing Android's dominant position in smartphone operating systems to protect its mobile-advertising business. Based on multiple anonymous sources, the WSJ report said that the fine could surpass the $2.8 billion the commission charged Google for abusing its search dominance last year. The companies did not disclose terms of the deal for AlienVault, which has raised $116.4 million in venture capital, according to FactSet. AT&T said the purchase would not have a material effect on its results, nor affect its plan to reduce its debt-to-profit ratio. "AlienVault's expertise in threat intelligence will improve our ability to help organizations detect and respond to cybersecurity attacks," AT&T's chief executive for the AT&T Business unit, Thaddeus Arroyo, said in Tuesday's announcement. AlienVault was backed by venture investors including Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers and Intel Corp.'s 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    INTC, -2.57%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         Intel Capital. AT&T shares were trading about 0.2% higher in Tuesday trading, and have decreased 17.1% so far this year, as the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 4.1%.
title: AT&T to acquire cybersecurity startup

author: GregRobb
content: A glitch in the new tax law is hurting retailers and fast-food chains, the Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday. The goof prevents these firms from deducting their renovation costs immediately, rather than over many years. Republican lawmakers are eager to make a fix but any change would require 60 votes in the Senate where Democrats have been reluctant to correct flaws in the measure.
title: Error in new tax law hurting retailers and fast-food chains: WSJ

author: JeffryBartash
content:
U.S. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross acknowledged last week he sold shares of a stock well after he had promised to divest his holdings, saying he had basically lost track of his investment. The Washington Post says Ross told a government ethics agency that some 1,631 shares he owned in Air Lease Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AL, +2.17%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         were held in a separate account under a different name than most of his investments. The shares sold in early June were worth between $50,000 and $100,000. Ross was a director for Air Lease from 2010 to 2013. His shares were listed under the name Wilbur L. Ross while most of his other stocks were owned under the name Wilbur Ross, the Commerce secretary said.
title: Commerce chief Ross admits to selling Air Lease stock

"After three quarters of stagnant stock performance and four quarters of disappointing guidance from Check Point, we believe it is now time to get constructive on the name again," he wrote. Fishbein had been looking for signs that the company's sales force was becoming more effective and that the company had finally hit its trough. "We believe both of the criteria are now true," he wrote. Shares of the security company are little changed over the past year, while the S&P 500

author: TomiKilgore
content:
Shares of Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc.

                                         decliners, after Evercore ISI downgraded the drug store chain citing a "long litany" of potential headwinds. Analyst Ross Muken cut his rating to in line from outperform, but raised his price target to $67 from $64. He said, "Typically I hate reactive downgrades," but in this case he struggled to find a coherent thesis on why Walgreens's stock should outperform after Amazon.com Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AMZN, -0.64%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         said it was buying online pharmacy PillPack. "The current wall of worry is simply too high to climb in our view, as [Amazon] risk joins drug pricing uncertainty, front end erosion, [European Union] fee pressure, and Brexit volatility," Muken wrote in a note to clients. Walgreens' stock has now dropped 5.7% since it entered the Dow after the June 25 close. Meanwhile, General Electric Co.'s stock 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    GE, -1.31%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         which Walgreens replaced in the Dow, has run up 11% and the Dow has tacked on 2.8%.

author: TonyaGarcia
content:
Nordstrom Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    JWN, +0.06%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares are down 4.2% in Tuesday trading after the department store retailer announced 2018 sales guidance that's below the FactSet consensus. Nordstrom is hosting its investor day today. Nordstrom expects fiscal 2018 sales of $15.2 billion to $15.4 billion, lower than the $15.8 billion FactSet consensus. Same-store sales are expected to be up 0.5% to 1.5% and diluted earnings per share are expected to be $3.35 to $3.35. The FactSet consensus is for a same-store sales increase of 0.8% and EPS of $4.54. For the long term, sales are expected to grow 3% to 4% on an average annualized basis from 2017 to 2022, and earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) is expected to grow 5% to 6% on an average annualized basis for the period. Nordstrom was downgraded to sector weight at KeyBanc Capital Markets based on the cost of competing with Amazon.com Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AMZN, -0.64%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         which continues to build its apparel business, and Stitch Fix Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SFIX, +4.91%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         which has a "data-focused approach," analysts said. "At Nordstrom, e-commerce is now 25% of sales, but inconsistent full-line comps point to channel substitution," wrote analysts led by Edward Yruma. "We remain impressed by Nordstrom's openness to reinventing itself - fortuitous investments in e-commerce and Rack have given the retailer a fairly unique level of stability. However, initiatives like pop-ups, product exclusives, and remodels have been unable to counter the natural traffic migration to e-commerce at the full-line stores." Moreover, it will be costly to maintain these efforts. Nordstrom announced Monday that it will add two new Local stores in California, building on its small-format, highly-personalized store design. Nordstrom shares are up 8.3% for 2018 to date, while the S&P 500 index has rallied 4.4% for the period.
title: Nordstrom shares slide after below-consensus revenue guidance announced

Of the eight analysts tracked by FactSet and who cover StitchFix, four have buy ratings and the other four have hold ratings. author: MarkDeCambre
content:
U.S. stocks opened higher Tuesday, setting the main indexes up for a fourth straight advance on the back of strong economic data that have thus far offset a recent bout of trade-related jitters. The Dow Jones Industrial Average

                                         climbed 100 points, or 0.5%, at 24,884, a day after it rallied by 320 points. A fourth session in the green for the blue-chip gauge would represent its longest string of wins since a similar stretch ended June 11, according to FactSet data. the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                                    COMP, -0.67%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         rose 0.1% at 7,767. Investors are gearing up for a rush of corporate results, which are poised to extend a run of double-digit growth enjoyed in the previous quarter on the back of corporate tax cuts enacted at the end of 2017. Wall Street is trying to shake off linger concerns of market-disruptive trade disputes between the U.S. and its partners in China, North America and Europe. In corporate news, PepsiCo Inc.'s

author: SarahToy
content:
Netflix, Inc. is launching a new feature, "Smart Downloads," aimed at its users who download episodes to watch on their phones or tablets while on the go, the company announced Tuesday. The feature will delete an episode after a user watches it, and will then automatically download the next episode while the device is connected to Wi-Fi "so your data plan will never be used, and it won't impact your device storage," the company said. Netflix

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    NFLX, -1.00%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         introduced its initial "Download" feature in 2016, allowing subscribers to download shows in addition to streaming at no extra cost. "One thing has been clear--members love downloading and enjoying Netflix on the go," director of production innovation Cameron Johnson said in a blog post Tuesday. "The faster you can get to the next episode you want to watch, the better," he said. Smart Downloads is currently available on Android phones and tabloids. Netflix shares are up 118% so far this year, while the S&P 500

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has risen 4.3%.
title: Netflix launches feature that will automatically delete old episodes and download new ones on mobile devices

author: TomiKilgore
content:
Shares of IsoRay Inc.

The company said it reached agreements to sell 11 million shares to institutional investors at 75 cents a share, which was 30% below Monday's closing price of $1.07. The offering would increase shares outstanding by about 20%. IsoRay also issued the investors warrants to buy 5.5 million shares, exercisable at 75 cents a share. On Monday, the stock soared 143% after the company announced Food and Drug Administration clearance for the brachytherapy technology, known as GammaTile Therapy. IsoRay's stock has rallied 74.5% over the past 12 months through Monday, while the S&P 500

content:
Shares of Spotify Technology SA

                                         are down 0.4% in premarket trading after Oppenheimer analyst Jason Helfstein initiated coverage of the stock with a perform rating. "We question whether scale begets market leadership in music streaming, as it does in many other internet-enabled industries," Helfstein wrote. He said that the ability to drive up engagement using machine-learning algorithms is "overestimated, and will diminish over time." Helfstein also doubts that the company will be able to improve its gross margins much through renegotiating deals with the record labels. Spotify's stock is up 15% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500

author: TomiKilgore
content:
Shares of Wynn Resorts Ltd. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    WYNN, -2.49%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         hiked up 1.4% in premarket trade Tuesday, after Stifel Nicolaus turned bullish on the casino operator, citing a "compelling" reward-versus-risk scenario as recent macro concerns appear overblown. Analyst Steven Wieczynski raised his rating to buy, after being at hold for at least the past two years. The stock has tumbled 21% from its May 10 record close of $201.51 through Monday--the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 2.2% over the same time--amid concerns over Chinese market conditions if a trade war with the U.S. escalates, worries about the health of the stock market and the World Cup soccer tournament have kept high rollers away from Macau over the past month. Wieczynski said his upgrade might be a bit early, but said that World Cup is nearly over, and there hasn't been a huge correlation between VIP play at casinos over the long term and stock market turmoil. And the recent selloff in the stock suggests buyside expectations are now more realistic, and that the macro environment only has to remain "somewhat status quo" to produce upside. In addition, headline risk, which includes the fallout from allegations of sexual misconduct by Founder Steven Wynn, has been diminished.
title: Wynn Resorts' stock rallies after Stifel Nicolaus analyst turns bullish

That would be the fifth facility in Ontario. Currently, Amazon employs 2,000 full-time associates in Ontario and has more than 6,000 employees in Canada. The company's 2017 annual report said it had 566,000 employees as of Dec. 31. Amazon's stock was little changed in premarket trade. It has soared 21% over the past three months, to close Monday at $1,739.02, or just 0.6% below its June 20 record close of $1,750.08. author: EmilyBary
content:
Jefferies analyst John Hecht assumed coverage of Square Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SQ, +1.76%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         with a hold rating on Tuesday, lowering the firm's price target to $60 from $63. A prior Jefferies analyst had rated the stock a buy. Shares are down 0.9% in premarket trading. Hecht sees potential for Square due to a secular shift toward electronic, mobile, and contactless payments, but he is concerned about competitive pressures and credit exposure. "Notwithstanding the opportunities, we believe that investors also need to balance this with considerations of risks - including competition and high growth targets in nascent business segments, which requires strong execution," he wrote. Hecht said that the Square Capital segment, which provides small-business loans, "would experience pressure in a recession." He also assumed coverage of PayPal Holdings Inc.

                                         has gained 15%.

author: TomiKilgore
content:
Shares of KB Home 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    KBH, -0.83%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         rallied 3.3% toward a three-month high in premarket trade Tuesday, after Susquehanna turned bullish on the home builder, citing strong housing trends in most of the markets KB Home operates. Analyst Jack Micenko raised his rating to positive, after being at neutral for at least the past three years, and raised his stock price target to $36 from $34. Micenko said he sees a "clear and visible path" to further gross margin expansion and a re-acceleration in community count and order growth into 2019. He said he was eyeing an upgrade for several months, but waited to see the impact of the negative perception of rising interest rates. "We believe there is not doubt that rising rates will ultimately pressure affordability broadly, but we think it will be at much higher levels--our work suggests 6% mortgage rates," Micenko wrote. During the July 5 week, 30-year fixed rate mortgages averaged 4.52%. KB Home's stock has shed 14% year to date through Monday, while the SPDR S&P Homebuilders ETF

author: TomiKilgore
content:
EBay Inc.'s stock 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    EBAY, -0.18%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         dropped 1.6% in premarket trade Tuesday, after the e-commerce company was downgraded at SunTrust Robinson Humphrey, citing expected headwinds from changes to sales-tax laws. Analyst Youssef Squali cut his rating to hold, after being at buy since Jan. 12, and lowered his stock price target to $40 from $48. Squali said he believes the U.S. Supreme Court ruling last month to reverse the 1992 precedent that states can require collection of sales tax without a physical presence increases the likelihood of a slowdown in gross merchandise value growth in 2019 and beyond. He said the new law reclassifies eBay as a "broker," which would require all sales to be reported to the IRS. "Logistically, we believe this is a daunting task for eBay as sellers would need to provide eBay with a social security or federal tax ID number, and report their profits to the IRS," Squali wrote in a note to clients. EBay's stock has lost 4.2% over the past three months through Monday, while the SPDR Consumer Discretionary Select Sector ETF 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    XLY, -0.84%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has rallied 9.8% and the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 4.8%.
title: EBay's stock drops after analyst downgrade on concern over SCOTUS's tax ruling

author: CiaraLinnane
content:
Celgene Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    CELG, -0.77%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         reported positive results from a late-stage trial of a treatment for breast cancer Tuesday, saying the trial met its co-primary endpoint of progression-free survival. The trial, which was sponsored by Roche, involved 902 patients and sought to evaluate the combination of the investigational combination TECENTRIQ plus ABRAXANE in triple negative breast cancer, a type that has a high unmet need. "This is the first phase III study to demonstrate a statistically significant PFS improvement in first-line metastatic or unresectable locally advanced triple negative breast cancer (TNBC)," Celgene said in a statement. The results will be presented at a coming medical meeting. Celgene shares rose 2% premarket on the news but have fallen 19.7% in 2018 through Monday, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 4.1%.
title: Celgene reports positive results in late-stage trial of treatment for breast cancer

Capacity rose 3.3% to 41.49 billion available seat miles, while traffic grew 2.2% to 35.14 billion revenue passenger miles. Enplaned passengers increased 3.6% to 42.93 million. Load factor fell to 86.9% from 87.4% in the month of June, but year to date, load factor rose to 83.2% from 82.9%. Southwest is slated to report second-quarter earnings on July 26, before the open. author: TomiKilgore
content:
Shares of PepsiCo Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    PEP, -0.73%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         rallied 1.7% in premarket trade Tuesday, after the beverage and snack giant reported fiscal second-quarter profit and revenue that rose above expectations. Net earnings for the quarter to June 16 fell to $1.82 billion, or $1.28 a share, from $2.11 billion, or $1.46 a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, core earnings per share rose 8% to $1.61, above the FactSet consensus of $1.53. Revenue rose 2% to $16.09 billion, topping the FactSet consensus of $16.06 billion. In North America, Frito-Lay revenue rose 4% to $3.84 billion, beating the FactSet consensus of $3.79 billion, while beverage revenue slipped 1% to $5.19 billion but was above expectations of $5.18 billion. Quaker Foods North America revenue fell 5% to $527 million, below the FactSet consensus of $550.7 million. Pepsi reiterated its 2018 outlook for core EPS of $5.70 and for organic revenue growth to be "at least in line" with 2017 growth of 2.3%. The stock has tumbled 10% year to date through Monday, while the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 4.1%.
title: Pepsi's stock jumps after core earnings, revenue rise above expectations

author: SteveGoldstein
content: The National Federation of Independent Business small-business optimism index fell 0.6 points to 107.2, a level that is still high by historical standards. The NFIB reported that the percent of owners who reported higher net sales fell 5 points. Since Dec. 2016, the index has averaged 105.4, well above the 45-year average of 98.
title: Small-business sentiment dampens slightly in June from high level, NFIB says

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
Altaba Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    AABA, +0.68%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         the holding company that used to be Yahoo Inc., announced Monday afternoon that it will sell about a third of its remaining stake in Yahoo Japan Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    4689, -2.44%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         to the other large stakeholder in the Asian asset, Softbank Group Corp. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    9984, -0.49%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         Altaba said that Softbank had agreed to buy 613,888,888 share of Yahoo Japan for $3.26 a share, about $2 billion in total. Altaba would still hold about 1.36 billion shares in Yahoo Japan if they sell all the shares, though Japanese law requires that Softbank make an open tender that allows for any Yahoo Japan shareholder to sell shares to Softbank in the tender offer. Yahoo Japan, however, has launched a concurrent buyback offer that seeks more than 600 million shares. Altaba and Softbank also terminated their joint venture agreement that gave the two Yahoo Japan owners stated rights, though Altaba retained some rights regarding extraordinary transactions. Altaba has been looking for ways to cash in on some of the investments that remain in the Zombie Yahoo's coffers, mostly its stake in Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    BABA, +1.59%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         but are having trouble convincing investors to take advantage. Altaba said this move had no effect on the other tender offer it has made. Altaba shares closed 0.3% higher Monday and added another 0.5% in late trading after the announcement was made.
title: Altaba to sell part of Yahoo Japan stake to Softbank for $2 billion

                                         shares pushed higher in the extended session Monday after the biotech companies said a clinical trial showed their jointly developed drug was effective in treating a certain type of inherited blood disorder. Celgene shares advanced 1.3% after hours, following a 1.7% gain to close the regular session at $83.85, while Acceleron shares rallied 9.2% after hours, following a 1.5% gain to close at $47.40. The companies said the drug luspatercept significantly lowered the rate of transfusions needed in patients with transfusion-dependent beta-thalassemia, a blood disorder where abnormal hemoglobin production causes anemia.
title: Celgene, Acceleron shares rise on blood-disorder drug study

author: AnnekenTappe
content:
Turkey's lira sharply sold off late Monday after President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced the picks for his cabinet. Thanks to a referendum last year that extended presidential powers, Erdogan can appoint ministers without parliamentary approval. The former president was re-inaugurated on Monday. Among his ministerial choices is his son-in-law Berat Albayrak as finance minister. The lira 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    USDTRY, +6.1875%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         plummeted more than 3% against the dollar in response. One dollar last bought 4.7167 lira, up from 4.5731 lira late Friday in New York. Earlier Monday, Turkey removed a clause setting the term for its central bank governor, which led the lira to pair previous gains. Investors have been concerned about the central bank's independence and what the new presidential powers could mean for Turkey as an investment destination.
title: Turkish lira sells off sells off after Erdogan appoints son-in-law as finance minister

The Local stores are smaller in size, offer personalized services, but don't house inventory. The smaller of the two will be a 1,200-square-foot location in Brentwood. The other, with about 2,200 square feet, will be in Los Angeles. Services include onsite tailoring and curbside pickup. The first Local store opened in Los Angeles in October 2017. author: SarahToy
content:
Netflix's valuation is approaching that of legacy media businesses on a per subscriber basis, analysts at Barclay said on Thursday, raising their price target for the streaming company to $450 from $370. When valuing Netflix

                                         on a per subscriber basis, the company's "valuation is not too far off from legacy media businesses, which are growing significantly slower," they wrote. Barclays is maintaining a stock rating of overweight, but analysts voiced some concerns about Netflix's "deluge of originals on the service," which they said could "worsen user experience by making content discovery more difficult." Analysts also noted Netflix's ability to raise debt at lower rates than its junk rating would suggest, writing that the turning of the credit cycle could be particularly disruptive if the company cannot turn cash flow positive in the next 2 to 3 years. Netflix shares have shot up 117% so far this year, while the S&P 500

                                         has risen 4.1%.
title: Barclays raises price target for Netflix to $450 from $370

author: JeremyC.Owens
content:
Twitter Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    TWTR, +0.16%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         executives responded Monday morning to a report that suggested an effort to clear out some fake accounts could affect its user numbers, throwing some water on the stock's scorching path lower. The Washington Post reported late Friday that Twitter had doubled its rate of account suspensions and kicked out 70 million accounts in May and June, a move that could endanger the user numbers that investors watch closely. On the social-network's service Monday, Chief Financial Officer Ned Segal clarified that most of the accounts were not active in the previous thirty days, and thus would not be counted in Twitter's preferred "monthly active user" metric. "If we removed 70M accounts from our reported metrics, you would hear directly from us," Segal said in a thread that was retweeted by Chief Executive Jack Dorsey. Twitter stock was headed for its worst day since March on Monday, the first trading session since the report was released, but rebounded after Segal's tweets. Shares were still down more than 5% just before 2 p.m. Eastern time. Twitter stock has been on a tear this year, increasing 84.3% while the S&P 500 index 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         has gained 3.2%
title: Twitter stock rebounds as CFO clarifies effects of fake account cleanup

author: ClaudiaAssis
content: Bloom Energy Corp. has set the terms of its initial public offering, seeking to sell 18 million shares between $13 and $15 a piece to raise up to $252 million, according to a filing Monday. Bloom, a clean-energy "unicorn," or a privately held startup valued at more than $1 billion, had filed the initial paperwork last month with a placeholder amount of $100 million. The Sunnyvale, Calif., company hopes to trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol BE. Underwriters include J.P. Morgan, Morgan Stanley, and Credit Suisse.
title: Bloom Energy sets IPO terms, seeking to sell up to $252 million in shares

author: SueChang
content:
Strategists at Bank of America Merrill Lynch on Monday raised the S&P 500 earnings target for 2018 by 4% to $159, citing firmer oil prices and stronger economic growth. "Higher oil prices are a benefit to S&P 500 EPS, where much of the index either produces commodities or supplies commodity producers," said Jill Carey Hall, an equity and quant strategist at BAML. The research team expects WTI/Brent to average $65 to $70 a barrel in 2018, roughly 25% higher than initially forecast earlier this year. "Nearly 40% of the boost to our earnings forecasts both this year and next year comes from energy," said Hall. The U.S. economy is also expanding faster than expected with BAML economists projecting 2018 gross domestic product to rise 3%, 0.1 percentage point higher than the previous forecast. A one percentage point increase in GDP boosts EPS growth by around 3 percentage points, the strategists said. Second-quarter earnings season is scheduled to kick off later this week with big banks reporting. BAML strategists are projecting second-quarter S&P 500 earnings to rise more than 20% to $39.75. The S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         rose 0.8% to 2,781 Monday on the back of robust bank stocks while the Dow Jones Industrial Average 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    DJIA, -0.77%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         gained by triple digits to 24,761.
title: Bank of America raises 2018 S&P 500 earnings target by 4% to $159

author: SteveGoldstein
content: President Donald Trump's former personal driver has sued for not paying overtime, according to a lawsuit filed by Noel Cintron. Cintron's complaint in the New York State Supreme Court alleges that he worked approximately 550 hours of overtime every year but didn't get paid time-and-a-half in violation of federal rules. The lawsuit says Cintron was the driver for Trump, members of his family and businesses for over 25 years.
title: Trump's former driver sues for overtime pay

author: EmmaCourt
content:
Acadia Pharmaceuticals Inc. 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    ACAD, +7.26%

                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                         shares tumbled 5% in heavy Monday midday trade after a report by the Southern Investigative Reporting Foundation's Roddy Boyd raised major concerns about the benefits and risks of the company's sole drug, Nuplazid, as well as Acadia's sales tactics. The report, which was published Monday morning and titled "Acadia Pharmaceuticals: This Is Not a Pharmaceuticals Company," found that the company used regulatory loopholes to get Nuplazid -- an anti-psychotic for Parkinson's disease -- approved, which allegedly masked issues with how safe the drug is and how well it works. The drug has been heavily marketed for use in patients with dementia in long-term care facilities. Though there is a warning on the drug about safety issues with that population, the most safety issues, or adverse events, with the drug nevertheless occurred within that group, according to the report. The report also questions the company's sales tactics, describing them as: "In a word, Acadia didn't just open up its corporate wallet for doctors: It pointed a hose and sprayed cash at them." Another company mentioned unfavorably in the report, Otsuka Holdings Co.'s Avanir Pharmaceuticals 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    4578, -0.58%

Acadia shares have risen nearly 3% over the last three months, compared with a 6.3% rise in the S&P 500 

                            
                            
                                  
      
      
      
      
      
      
      
                                  
                                    SPX, -0.71%

                                    DJIA, -0.77%
title: Acadia shares tumble 5% after investigative report raises concerns about its sole drug
